21  doc: Start time of epoch, in seconds.
22- name: stop_time
23  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
24  dtype: float32
25  doc: Stop time of epoch, in seconds.
26- name: tags
27  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
28  dtype: text
29  doc: User-defined tags that identify or categorize events.
30  quantity: '?'
31- name: tags_index
32  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
33  doc: Index for tags.
34  quantity: '?'
35- name: timeseries
36  neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeriesReferenceVectorData
37  doc: An index into a TimeSeries object.
38  quantity: '?'
39- name: timeseries_index
40  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
41  doc: Index for timeseries.
42  quantity: '?'
43- name: id
44  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
45  dtype: int
46  dims:
47  - num_rows
48  shape:
49  - null
50  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
51- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
52  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
53  quantity: '*'

3.5. Image data

This source module contains neurodata_types for image data.

3.5.1. GrayscaleImage

Extends: Image

Description: see Section 2.4.1

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: GrayscaleImage
 2neurodata_type_inc: Image
 3dtype: numeric
 4dims:
 5- x
 6- y
 7shape:
 8- null
 9- null
10doc: A grayscale image.
11attributes:
12- name: resolution
13  dtype: float32
14  doc: Pixel resolution of the image, in pixels per centimeter.
15  required: false
16- name: description
17  dtype: text
18  doc: Description of the image.
19  required: false

3.5.2. RGBImage

Extends: Image

Description: see Section 2.4.2

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: RGBImage
 2neurodata_type_inc: Image
 3dtype: numeric
 4dims:
 5- x
 6- y
 7- r, g, b
 8shape:
 9- null
10- null
11- 3
12doc: A color image.
13attributes:
14- name: resolution
15  dtype: float32
16  doc: Pixel resolution of the image, in pixels per centimeter.
17  required: false
18- name: description
19  dtype: text
20  doc: Description of the image.
21  required: false

3.5.3. RGBAImage

Extends: Image

Description: see Section 2.4.3

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: RGBAImage
 2neurodata_type_inc: Image
 3dtype: numeric
 4dims:
 5- x
 6- y
 7- r, g, b, a
 8shape:
 9- null
10- null
11- 4
12doc: A color image with transparency.
13attributes:
14- name: resolution
15  dtype: float32
16  doc: Pixel resolution of the image, in pixels per centimeter.
17  required: false
18- name: description
19  dtype: text
20  doc: Description of the image.
21  required: false

3.5.4. ImageSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.4.4

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: ImageSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: General image data that is common between acquisition and stimulus time
  4  series. Sometimes the image data is stored in the file in a raw format while
  5  other times it will be stored as a series of external image files in the host
  6  file system. The data field will either be binary data, if the data is stored
  7  in the NWB file, or empty, if the data is stored in an external image stack.
  8  [frame][x][y] or [frame][x][y][z].
  9attributes:
 10- name: description
 11  dtype: text
 12  default_value: no description
 13  doc: Description of the time series.
 14  required: false
 15- name: comments
 16  dtype: text
 17  default_value: no comments
 18  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 19    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 20    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 21    computer-readable string.
 22  required: false
 23datasets:
 24- name: data
 25  dtype: numeric
 26  dims:
 27  - - frame
 28    - x
 29    - y
 30  - - frame
 31    - x
 32    - y
 33    - z
 34  shape:
 35  - - null
 36    - null
 37    - null
 38  - - null
 39    - null
 40    - null
 41    - null
 42  doc: Binary data representing images across frames. If data are stored in an
 43    external file, this should be an empty 3D array.
 44  attributes:
 45  - name: conversion
 46    dtype: float32
 47    default_value: 1.0
 48    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 49      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 50      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 51      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 52      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 53      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 54      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 55      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 56      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 57    required: false
 58  - name: offset
 59    dtype: float32
 60    default_value: 0.0
 61    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 62      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 63      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 64      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 65      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 66    required: false
 67  - name: resolution
 68    dtype: float32
 69    default_value: -1.0
 70    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 71      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 72      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 73      -1.0.
 74    required: false
 75  - name: unit
 76    dtype: text
 77    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 78      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 79      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
 80  - name: continuity
 81    dtype: text
 82    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 83      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 84      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 85      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 86      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 87      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 88      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 89      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 90      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 91    required: false
 92- name: dimension
 93  dtype: int32
 94  dims:
 95  - rank
 96  shape:
 97  - null
 98  doc: Number of pixels on x, y, (and z) axes.
 99  quantity: '?'
100- name: external_file
101  dtype: text
102  dims:
103  - num_files
104  shape:
105  - null
106  doc: Paths to one or more external file(s). The field is only present if
107    format='external'. This is only relevant if the image series is stored in
108    the file system as one or more image file(s). This field should NOT be used
109    if the image is stored in another NWB file and that file is linked to this
110    file.
111  quantity: '?'
112  attributes:
113  - name: starting_frame
114    dtype: int32
115    dims:
116    - num_files
117    shape:
118    - null
119    doc: Each external image may contain one or more consecutive frames of the
120      full ImageSeries. This attribute serves as an index to indicate which
121      frames each file contains, to facilitate random access. The
122      'starting_frame' attribute, hence, contains a list of frame numbers within
123      the full ImageSeries of the first frame of each file listed in the parent
124      'external_file' dataset. Zero-based indexing is used (hence, the first
125      element will always be zero). For example, if the 'external_file' dataset
126      has three paths to files and the first file has 5 frames, the second file
127      has 10 frames, and the third file has 20 frames, then this attribute will
128      have values [0, 5, 15]. If there is a single external file that holds all
129      of the frames of the ImageSeries (and so there is a single element in the
130      'external_file' dataset), then this attribute should have value [0].
131- name: format
132  dtype: text
133  default_value: raw
134  doc: Format of image. If this is 'external', then the attribute
135    'external_file' contains the path information to the image files. If this is
136    'raw', then the raw (single-channel) binary data is stored in the 'data'
137    dataset. If this attribute is not present, then the default format='raw'
138    case is assumed.
139  quantity: '?'
140- name: starting_time
141  dtype: float64
142  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
143    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
144    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
145  quantity: '?'
146  attributes:
147  - name: rate
148    dtype: float32
149    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
150  - name: unit
151    dtype: text
152    value: seconds
153    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
154- name: timestamps
155  dtype: float64
156  dims:
157  - num_times
158  shape:
159  - null
160  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
161    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
162  quantity: '?'
163  attributes:
164  - name: interval
165    dtype: int32
166    value: 1
167    doc: Value is '1'
168  - name: unit
169    dtype: text
170    value: seconds
171    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
172- name: control
173  dtype: uint8
174  dims:
175  - num_times
176  shape:
177  - null
178  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
179    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
180    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
181  quantity: '?'
182- name: control_description
183  dtype: text
184  dims:
185  - num_control_values
186  shape:
187  - null
188  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
189    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
190    == 0.
191  quantity: '?'
192groups:
193- name: sync
194  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
195    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
196    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
197    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
198    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
199    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
200  quantity: '?'
201links:
202- name: device
203  target_type: Device
204  doc: Link to the Device object that was used to capture these images.
205  quantity: '?'

3.5.5. ImageMaskSeries

Extends: ImageSeries

Description: see Section 2.4.5

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: ImageMaskSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: ImageSeries
  3doc: DEPRECATED. An alpha mask that is applied to a presented visual stimulus.
  4  The 'data' array contains an array of mask values that are applied to the
  5  displayed image. Mask values are stored as RGBA. Mask can vary with time. The
  6  timestamps array indicates the starting time of a mask, and that mask pattern
  7  continues until it's explicitly changed.
  8attributes:
  9- name: description
 10  dtype: text
 11  default_value: no description
 12  doc: Description of the time series.
 13  required: false
 14- name: comments
 15  dtype: text
 16  default_value: no comments
 17  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 18    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 19    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 20    computer-readable string.
 21  required: false
 22datasets:
 23- name: data
 24  dtype: numeric
 25  dims:
 26  - - frame
 27    - x
 28    - y
 29  - - frame
 30    - x
 31    - y
 32    - z
 33  shape:
 34  - - null
 35    - null
 36    - null
 37  - - null
 38    - null
 39    - null
 40    - null
 41  doc: Binary data representing images across frames. If data are stored in an
 42    external file, this should be an empty 3D array.
 43  attributes:
 44  - name: conversion
 45    dtype: float32
 46    default_value: 1.0
 47    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 48      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 49      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 50      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 51      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 52      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 53      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 54      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 55      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 56    required: false
 57  - name: offset
 58    dtype: float32
 59    default_value: 0.0
 60    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 61      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 62      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 63      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 64      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 65    required: false
 66  - name: resolution
 67    dtype: float32
 68    default_value: -1.0
 69    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 70      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 71      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 72      -1.0.
 73    required: false
 74  - name: unit
 75    dtype: text
 76    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 77      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 78      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
 79  - name: continuity
 80    dtype: text
 81    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 82      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 83      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 84      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 85      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 86      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 87      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 88      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 89      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 90    required: false
 91- name: dimension
 92  dtype: int32
 93  dims:
 94  - rank
 95  shape:
 96  - null
 97  doc: Number of pixels on x, y, (and z) axes.
 98  quantity: '?'
 99- name: external_file
100  dtype: text
101  dims:
102  - num_files
103  shape:
104  - null
105  doc: Paths to one or more external file(s). The field is only present if
106    format='external'. This is only relevant if the image series is stored in
107    the file system as one or more image file(s). This field should NOT be used
108    if the image is stored in another NWB file and that file is linked to this
109    file.
110  quantity: '?'
111  attributes:
112  - name: starting_frame
113    dtype: int32
114    dims:
115    - num_files
116    shape:
117    - null
118    doc: Each external image may contain one or more consecutive frames of the
119      full ImageSeries. This attribute serves as an index to indicate which
120      frames each file contains, to facilitate random access. The
121      'starting_frame' attribute, hence, contains a list of frame numbers within
122      the full ImageSeries of the first frame of each file listed in the parent
123      'external_file' dataset. Zero-based indexing is used (hence, the first
124      element will always be zero). For example, if the 'external_file' dataset
125      has three paths to files and the first file has 5 frames, the second file
126      has 10 frames, and the third file has 20 frames, then this attribute will
127      have values [0, 5, 15]. If there is a single external file that holds all
128      of the frames of the ImageSeries (and so there is a single element in the
129      'external_file' dataset), then this attribute should have value [0].
130- name: format
131  dtype: text
132  default_value: raw
133  doc: Format of image. If this is 'external', then the attribute
134    'external_file' contains the path information to the image files. If this is
135    'raw', then the raw (single-channel) binary data is stored in the 'data'
136    dataset. If this attribute is not present, then the default format='raw'
137    case is assumed.
138  quantity: '?'
139- name: starting_time
140  dtype: float64
141  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
142    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
143    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
144  quantity: '?'
145  attributes:
146  - name: rate
147    dtype: float32
148    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
149  - name: unit
150    dtype: text
151    value: seconds
152    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
153- name: timestamps
154  dtype: float64
155  dims:
156  - num_times
157  shape:
158  - null
159  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
160    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
161  quantity: '?'
162  attributes:
163  - name: interval
164    dtype: int32
165    value: 1
166    doc: Value is '1'
167  - name: unit
168    dtype: text
169    value: seconds
170    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
171- name: control
172  dtype: uint8
173  dims:
174  - num_times
175  shape:
176  - null
177  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
178    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
179    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
180  quantity: '?'
181- name: control_description
182  dtype: text
183  dims:
184  - num_control_values
185  shape:
186  - null
187  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
188    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
189    == 0.
190  quantity: '?'
191groups:
192- name: sync
193  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
194    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
195    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
196    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
197    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
198    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
199  quantity: '?'
200links:
201- name: masked_imageseries
202  target_type: ImageSeries
203  doc: Link to ImageSeries object that this image mask is applied to.
204- name: device
205  target_type: Device
206  doc: Link to the Device object that was used to capture these images.
207  quantity: '?'

3.5.6. OpticalSeries

Extends: ImageSeries

Description: see Section 2.4.6

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: OpticalSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: ImageSeries
  3doc: Image data that is presented or recorded. A stimulus template movie will be
  4  stored only as an image. When the image is presented as stimulus, additional
  5  data is required, such as field of view (e.g., how much of the visual field
  6  the image covers, or how what is the area of the target being imaged). If the
  7  OpticalSeries represents acquired imaging data, orientation is also important.
  8attributes:
  9- name: description
 10  dtype: text
 11  default_value: no description
 12  doc: Description of the time series.
 13  required: false
 14- name: comments
 15  dtype: text
 16  default_value: no comments
 17  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 18    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 19    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 20    computer-readable string.
 21  required: false
 22datasets:
 23- name: distance
 24  dtype: float32
 25  doc: Distance from camera/monitor to target/eye.
 26  quantity: '?'
 27- name: field_of_view
 28  dtype: float32
 29  dims:
 30  - - width, height
 31  - - width, height, depth
 32  shape:
 33  - - 2
 34  - - 3
 35  doc: Width, height and depth of image, or imaged area, in meters.
 36  quantity: '?'
 37- name: data
 38  dtype: numeric
 39  dims:
 40  - - frame
 41    - x
 42    - y
 43  - - frame
 44    - x
 45    - y
 46    - r, g, b
 47  shape:
 48  - - null
 49    - null
 50    - null
 51  - - null
 52    - null
 53    - null
 54    - 3
 55  doc: Images presented to subject, either grayscale or RGB
 56  attributes:
 57  - name: conversion
 58    dtype: float32
 59    default_value: 1.0
 60    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 61      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 62      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 63      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 64      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 65      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 66      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 67      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 68      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 69    required: false
 70  - name: offset
 71    dtype: float32
 72    default_value: 0.0
 73    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 74      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 75      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 76      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 77      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 78    required: false
 79  - name: resolution
 80    dtype: float32
 81    default_value: -1.0
 82    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 83      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 84      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 85      -1.0.
 86    required: false
 87  - name: unit
 88    dtype: text
 89    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 90      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 91      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
 92  - name: continuity
 93    dtype: text
 94    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 95      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 96      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 97      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 98      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 99      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
100      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
101      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
102      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
103    required: false
104- name: orientation
105  dtype: text
106  doc: Description of image relative to some reference frame (e.g., which way is
107    up). Must also specify frame of reference.
108  quantity: '?'
109- name: dimension
110  dtype: int32
111  dims:
112  - rank
113  shape:
114  - null
115  doc: Number of pixels on x, y, (and z) axes.
116  quantity: '?'
117- name: external_file
118  dtype: text
119  dims:
120  - num_files
121  shape:
122  - null
123  doc: Paths to one or more external file(s). The field is only present if
124    format='external'. This is only relevant if the image series is stored in
125    the file system as one or more image file(s). This field should NOT be used
126    if the image is stored in another NWB file and that file is linked to this
127    file.
128  quantity: '?'
129  attributes:
130  - name: starting_frame
131    dtype: int32
132    dims:
133    - num_files
134    shape:
135    - null
136    doc: Each external image may contain one or more consecutive frames of the
137      full ImageSeries. This attribute serves as an index to indicate which
138      frames each file contains, to facilitate random access. The
139      'starting_frame' attribute, hence, contains a list of frame numbers within
140      the full ImageSeries of the first frame of each file listed in the parent
141      'external_file' dataset. Zero-based indexing is used (hence, the first
142      element will always be zero). For example, if the 'external_file' dataset
143      has three paths to files and the first file has 5 frames, the second file
144      has 10 frames, and the third file has 20 frames, then this attribute will
145      have values [0, 5, 15]. If there is a single external file that holds all
146      of the frames of the ImageSeries (and so there is a single element in the
147      'external_file' dataset), then this attribute should have value [0].
148- name: format
149  dtype: text
150  default_value: raw
151  doc: Format of image. If this is 'external', then the attribute
152    'external_file' contains the path information to the image files. If this is
153    'raw', then the raw (single-channel) binary data is stored in the 'data'
154    dataset. If this attribute is not present, then the default format='raw'
155    case is assumed.
156  quantity: '?'
157- name: starting_time
158  dtype: float64
159  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
160    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
161    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
162  quantity: '?'
163  attributes:
164  - name: rate
165    dtype: float32
166    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
167  - name: unit
168    dtype: text
169    value: seconds
170    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
171- name: timestamps
172  dtype: float64
173  dims:
174  - num_times
175  shape:
176  - null
177  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
178    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
179  quantity: '?'
180  attributes:
181  - name: interval
182    dtype: int32
183    value: 1
184    doc: Value is '1'
185  - name: unit
186    dtype: text
187    value: seconds
188    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
189- name: control
190  dtype: uint8
191  dims:
192  - num_times
193  shape:
194  - null
195  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
196    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
197    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
198  quantity: '?'
199- name: control_description
200  dtype: text
201  dims:
202  - num_control_values
203  shape:
204  - null
205  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
206    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
207    == 0.
208  quantity: '?'
209groups:
210- name: sync
211  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
212    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
213    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
214    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
215    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
216    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
217  quantity: '?'
218links:
219- name: device
220  target_type: Device
221  doc: Link to the Device object that was used to capture these images.
222  quantity: '?'

3.5.7. IndexSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.4.7

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: IndexSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: Stores indices that reference images defined in other containers. The
  4  primary purpose of the IndexSeries is to allow images stored in an Images
  5  container to be referenced in a specific sequence through the 'indexed_images'
  6  link. This approach avoids duplicating image data when the same image needs to
  7  be presented multiple times or when images need to be shown in a different
  8  order than they are stored. Since images in an Images container do not have an
  9  inherent order, the Images container needs to include an 'order_of_images'
 10  dataset (of type ImageReferences) when being referenced by an IndexSeries.
 11  This dataset establishes the ordered sequence that the indices in IndexSeries
 12  refer to. The 'data' field stores the index into this ordered sequence, and
 13  the 'timestamps' array indicates the precise presentation time of each indexed
 14  image during an experiment. This can be used for displaying individual images
 15  or creating movie segments by referencing a sequence of images with the
 16  appropriate timestamps. While IndexSeries can also reference frames from an
 17  ImageSeries through the 'indexed_timeseries' link, this usage is discouraged
 18  and will be deprecated in favor of using Images containers with
 19  'order_of_images'.
 20attributes:
 21- name: description
 22  dtype: text
 23  default_value: no description
 24  doc: Description of the time series.
 25  required: false
 26- name: comments
 27  dtype: text
 28  default_value: no comments
 29  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 30    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 31    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 32    computer-readable string.
 33  required: false
 34datasets:
 35- name: data
 36  dtype: uint32
 37  dims:
 38  - num_times
 39  shape:
 40  - null
 41  doc: Index of the image (using zero-indexing) in the linked Images object.
 42  attributes:
 43  - name: conversion
 44    dtype: float32
 45    doc: This field is unused by IndexSeries.
 46    required: false
 47  - name: resolution
 48    dtype: float32
 49    doc: This field is unused by IndexSeries.
 50    required: false
 51  - name: offset
 52    dtype: float32
 53    doc: This field is unused by IndexSeries.
 54    required: false
 55  - name: unit
 56    dtype: text
 57    value: N/A
 58    doc: This field is unused by IndexSeries and has the value N/A.
 59  - name: continuity
 60    dtype: text
 61    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 62      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 63      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 64      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 65      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 66      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 67      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 68      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 69      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 70    required: false
 71- name: starting_time
 72  dtype: float64
 73  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 74    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 75    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 76  quantity: '?'
 77  attributes:
 78  - name: rate
 79    dtype: float32
 80    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 81  - name: unit
 82    dtype: text
 83    value: seconds
 84    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 85- name: timestamps
 86  dtype: float64
 87  dims:
 88  - num_times
 89  shape:
 90  - null
 91  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
 92    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
 93  quantity: '?'
 94  attributes:
 95  - name: interval
 96    dtype: int32
 97    value: 1
 98    doc: Value is '1'
 99  - name: unit
100    dtype: text
101    value: seconds
102    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
103- name: control
104  dtype: uint8
105  dims:
106  - num_times
107  shape:
108  - null
109  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
110    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
111    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
112  quantity: '?'
113- name: control_description
114  dtype: text
115  dims:
116  - num_control_values
117  shape:
118  - null
119  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
120    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
121    == 0.
122  quantity: '?'
123groups:
124- name: sync
125  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
126    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
127    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
128    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
129    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
130    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
131  quantity: '?'
132links:
133- name: indexed_timeseries
134  target_type: ImageSeries
135  doc: Link to ImageSeries object containing images that are indexed. Use of
136    this link is discouraged and will be deprecated. Link to an Images type
137    instead.
138  quantity: '?'
139- name: indexed_images
140  target_type: Images
141  doc: Link to Images object containing an ordered set of images that are
142    indexed. The Images object must contain a 'ordered_images' dataset
143    specifying the order of the images in the Images type.
144  quantity: '?'

3.6. NWB file

Main NWB file specification.

3.6.1. ScratchData

Extends: NWBData

Description: see Section 2.5.1

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: ScratchData
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBData
3doc: Any one-off datasets
4attributes:
5- name: notes
6  dtype: text
7  doc: Any notes the user has about the dataset being stored

3.6.2. NWBFile

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.5.2

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: NWBFile
  2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
  3name: root
  4doc: An NWB file storing cellular-based neurophysiology data from a single
  5  experimental session.
  6attributes:
  7- name: nwb_version
  8  dtype: text
  9  value: 2.9.0
 10  doc: File version string. Use semantic versioning, e.g. 1.2.1. This will be
 11    the name of the format with trailing major, minor and patch numbers.
 12datasets:
 13- name: file_create_date
 14  dtype: isodatetime
 15  dims:
 16  - num_modifications
 17  shape:
 18  - null
 19  doc: 'A record of the date the file was created and of subsequent modifications.
 20    The date is stored in UTC with local timezone offset as ISO 8601 extended formatted
 21    strings: 2018-09-28T14:43:54.123+02:00. Dates stored in UTC end in "Z" with no
 22    timezone offset. Date accuracy is up to milliseconds. The file can be created
 23    after the experiment was run, so this may differ from the experiment start time.
 24    Each modification to the nwb file adds a new entry to the array.'
 25- name: identifier
 26  dtype: text
 27  doc: A unique text identifier for the file. For example, concatenated lab
 28    name, file creation date/time and experimentalist, or a hash of these and/or
 29    other values. The goal is that the string should be unique to all other
 30    files.
 31- name: session_description
 32  dtype: text
 33  doc: A description of the experimental session and data in the file.
 34- name: session_start_time
 35  dtype: isodatetime
 36  doc: 'Date and time of the experiment/session start. The date is stored in UTC with
 37    local timezone offset as ISO 8601 extended formatted string: 2018-09-28T14:43:54.123+02:00.
 38    Dates stored in UTC end in "Z" with no timezone offset. Date accuracy is up to
 39    milliseconds.'
 40- name: timestamps_reference_time
 41  dtype: isodatetime
 42  doc: 'Date and time corresponding to time zero of all timestamps. The date is stored
 43    in UTC with local timezone offset as ISO 8601 extended formatted string: 2018-09-28T14:43:54.123+02:00.
 44    Dates stored in UTC end in "Z" with no timezone offset. Date accuracy is up to
 45    milliseconds. All times stored in the file use this time as reference (i.e., time
 46    zero).'
 47groups:
 48- name: acquisition
 49  doc: Data streams recorded from the system, including ephys, ophys, tracking,
 50    etc. This group should be read-only after the experiment is completed and
 51    timestamps are corrected to a common timebase. The data stored here may be
 52    links to raw data stored in external NWB files. This will allow keeping
 53    bulky raw data out of the file while preserving the option of keeping
 54    some/all in the file. Acquired data includes tracking and experimental data
 55    streams (i.e., everything measured from the system). If bulky data is stored
 56    in the /acquisition group, the data can exist in a separate NWB file that is
 57    linked to by the file being used for processing and analysis.
 58  groups:
 59  - neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 60    doc: Acquired, raw data.
 61    quantity: '*'
 62  - neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 63    doc: Tabular data that is relevant to acquisition
 64    quantity: '*'
 65- name: analysis
 66  doc: Lab-specific and custom scientific analysis of data. There is no defined
 67    format for the content of this group - the format is up to the individual
 68    user/lab. To facilitate sharing analysis data between labs, the contents
 69    here should be stored in standard types (e.g., neurodata_types) and
 70    appropriately documented. The file can store lab-specific and custom data
 71    analysis without restriction on its form or schema, reducing data formatting
 72    restrictions on end users. Such data should be placed in the analysis group.
 73    The analysis data should be documented so that it could be shared with other
 74    labs.
 75  groups:
 76  - neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 77    doc: Custom analysis results.
 78    quantity: '*'
 79  - neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 80    doc: Tabular data that is relevant to data stored in analysis
 81    quantity: '*'
 82- name: scratch
 83  doc: A place to store one-off analysis results. Data placed here is not
 84    intended for sharing. By placing data here, users acknowledge that there is
 85    no guarantee that their data meets any standard.
 86  quantity: '?'
 87  datasets:
 88  - neurodata_type_inc: ScratchData
 89    doc: Any one-off datasets
 90    quantity: '*'
 91  groups:
 92  - neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 93    doc: Any one-off containers
 94    quantity: '*'
 95  - neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 96    doc: Any one-off tables
 97    quantity: '*'
 98- name: processing
 99  doc: The home for ProcessingModules. These modules perform intermediate
100    analysis of data that is necessary to perform before scientific analysis.
101    Examples include spike clustering, extracting position from tracking data,
102    stitching together image slices. ProcessingModules can be large and express
103    many data sets from relatively complex analysis (e.g., spike detection and
104    clustering) or small, representing extraction of position information from
105    tracking video, or even binary lick/no-lick decisions. Common software tools
106    (e.g., klustakwik, MClust) are expected to read/write data here.
107    'Processing' refers to intermediate analysis of the acquired data to make it
108    more amenable to scientific analysis.
109  groups:
110  - neurodata_type_inc: ProcessingModule
111    doc: Intermediate analysis of acquired data.
112    quantity: '*'
113- name: stimulus
114  doc: Data pushed into the system (eg, video stimulus, sound, voltage, etc) and
115    secondary representations of that data (eg, measurements of something used
116    as a stimulus). This group should be made read-only after experiment
117    complete and timestamps are corrected to common timebase. Stores both
118    presented stimuli and stimulus templates, the latter in case the same
119    stimulus is presented multiple times, or is pulled from an external stimulus
120    library. Stimuli are here defined as any signal that is pushed into the
121    system as part of the experiment (eg, sound, video, voltage, etc). Many
122    different experiments can use the same stimuli, and stimuli can be reused
123    during an experiment. The stimulus group is organized so that one version of
124    template stimuli can be stored and these be used multiple times. These
125    templates can exist in the present file or can be linked to a remote library
126    file.
127  groups:
128  - name: presentation
129    doc: Stimuli presented during the experiment.
130    groups:
131    - neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
132      doc: TimeSeries objects containing data of presented stimuli.
133      quantity: '*'
134    - neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
135      doc: Generic NWB data interfaces, usually from an extension, containing
136        data of presented stimuli.
137      quantity: '*'
138    - neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
139      doc: DynamicTable objects containing data of presented stimuli.
140      quantity: '*'
141  - name: templates
142    doc: Template stimuli. Timestamps in templates are based on stimulus design
143      and are relative to the beginning of the stimulus. When templates are
144      used, the stimulus instances must convert presentation times to the
145      experiment`s time reference frame.
146    groups:
147    - neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
148      doc: TimeSeries objects containing template data of presented stimuli.
149      quantity: '*'
150    - neurodata_type_inc: Images
151      doc: Images objects containing images of presented stimuli.
152      quantity: '*'
153- name: general
154  doc: Experimental metadata, including protocol, notes and description of
155    hardware device(s).  The metadata stored in this section should be used to
156    describe the experiment. Metadata necessary for interpreting the data is
157    stored with the data. General experimental metadata, including animal
158    strain, experimental protocols, experimenter, devices, etc, are stored under
159    'general'. Core metadata (e.g., that required to interpret data fields) is
160    stored with the data itself, and implicitly defined by the file
161    specification (e.g., time is in seconds). The strategy used here for storing
162    non-core metadata is to use free-form text fields, such as would appear in
163    sentences or paragraphs from a Methods section. Metadata fields are text to
164    enable them to be more general, for example to represent ranges instead of
165    numerical values. Machine-readable metadata is stored as attributes to these
166    free-form datasets. All entries in the below table are to be included when
167    data is present. Unused groups (e.g., intracellular_ephys in an
168    optophysiology experiment) should not be created unless there is data to
169    store within them.
170  datasets:
171  - name: data_collection
172    dtype: text
173    doc: Notes about data collection and analysis.
174    quantity: '?'
175  - name: experiment_description
176    dtype: text
177    doc: General description of the experiment.
178    quantity: '?'
179  - name: experimenter
180    dtype: text
181    dims:
182    - num_experimenters
183    shape:
184    - null
185    doc: Name of person(s) who performed the experiment. Can also specify roles
186      of different people involved.
187    quantity: '?'
188  - name: institution
189    dtype: text
190    doc: Institution(s) where experiment was performed.
191    quantity: '?'
192  - name: keywords
193    dtype: text
194    dims:
195    - num_keywords
196    shape:
197    - null
198    doc: Terms to search over.
199    quantity: '?'
200  - name: lab
201    dtype: text
202    doc: Laboratory where experiment was performed.
203    quantity: '?'
204  - name: notes
205    dtype: text
206    doc: Notes about the experiment.
207    quantity: '?'
208  - name: pharmacology
209    dtype: text
210    doc: Description of drugs used, including how and when they were
211      administered. Anesthesia(s), painkiller(s), etc., plus dosage,
212      concentration, etc.
213    quantity: '?'
214  - name: protocol
215    dtype: text
216    doc: Experimental protocol, if applicable. e.g., include IACUC protocol
217      number.
218    quantity: '?'
219  - name: related_publications
220    dtype: text
221    dims:
222    - num_publications
223    shape:
224    - null
225    doc: Publication information. PMID, DOI, URL, etc.
226    quantity: '?'
227  - name: session_id
228    dtype: text
229    doc: Lab-specific ID for the session.
230    quantity: '?'
231  - name: slices
232    dtype: text
233    doc: Description of slices, including information about preparation
234      thickness, orientation, temperature, and bath solution.
235    quantity: '?'
236  - name: source_script
237    dtype: text
238    doc: Script file or link to public source code used to create this NWB file.
239    quantity: '?'
240    attributes:
241    - name: file_name
242      dtype: text
243      doc: Name of script file.
244  - name: was_generated_by
245    dtype: text
246    dims:
247    - num_sources
248    - name, version
249    shape:
250    - null
251    - 2
252    doc: Name and version of software package(s) used to generate data contained
253      in this NWB File. For each software package or library, include the name
254      of the software as the first value and the version as the second value.
255    quantity: '?'
256  - name: stimulus
257    dtype: text
258    doc: Notes about stimuli, such as how and where they were presented.
259    quantity: '?'
260  - name: surgery
261    dtype: text
262    doc: Narrative description about surgery/surgeries, including date(s) and
263      who performed surgery.
264    quantity: '?'
265  - name: virus
266    dtype: text
267    doc: Information about virus(es) used in experiments, including virus ID,
268      source, date made, injection location, volume, etc.
269    quantity: '?'
270  groups:
271  - neurodata_type_inc: LabMetaData
272    doc: Place-holder than can be extended so that lab-specific meta-data can be
273      placed in /general.
274    quantity: '*'
275  - name: devices
276    doc: Description of hardware devices used during experiment, e.g., monitors,
277      ADC boards, microscopes, etc.
278    quantity: '?'
279    groups:
280    - neurodata_type_inc: Device
281      doc: Data acquisition devices.
282      quantity: '*'
283    - name: models
284      doc: Collection of data acquisition device models.
285      quantity: '?'
286      groups:
287      - neurodata_type_inc: DeviceModel
288        doc: Data acquisition device models.
289        quantity: '*'
290  - name: subject
291    neurodata_type_inc: Subject
292    doc: Information about the animal or person from which the data was
293      measured.
294    quantity: '?'
295  - name: extracellular_ephys
296    doc: Metadata related to extracellular electrophysiology.
297    quantity: '?'
298    groups:
299    - neurodata_type_inc: ElectrodeGroup
300      doc: Physical group of electrodes.
301      quantity: '*'
302    - name: electrodes
303      neurodata_type_inc: ElectrodesTable
304      doc: A table of all electrodes (i.e. channels) used for recording. Changed
305        in NWB 2.9.0 to use the newly added ElectrodesTable neurodata type
306        instead of a DynamicTable with added columns.
307      quantity: '?'
308  - name: intracellular_ephys
309    doc: Metadata related to intracellular electrophysiology.
310    quantity: '?'
311    datasets:
312    - name: filtering
313      dtype: text
314      doc: '[DEPRECATED] Use IntracellularElectrode.filtering instead. Description
315        of filtering used. Includes filtering type and parameters, frequency fall-off,
316        etc. If this changes between TimeSeries, filter description should be stored
317        as a text attribute for each TimeSeries.'
318      quantity: '?'
319    groups:
320    - neurodata_type_inc: IntracellularElectrode
321      doc: An intracellular electrode.
322      quantity: '*'
323    - name: sweep_table
324      neurodata_type_inc: SweepTable
325      doc: '[DEPRECATED] Table used to group different PatchClampSeries. SweepTable
326        is being replaced by IntracellularRecordingsTable and SimultaneousRecordingsTable
327        tables. Additional SequentialRecordingsTable, RepetitionsTable and ExperimentalConditions
328        tables provide enhanced support for experiment metadata.'
329      quantity: '?'
330    - name: intracellular_recordings
331      neurodata_type_inc: IntracellularRecordingsTable
332      doc: A table to group together a stimulus and response from a single
333        electrode and a single simultaneous recording. Each row in the table
334        represents a single recording consisting typically of a stimulus and a
335        corresponding response. In some cases, however, only a stimulus or a
336        response are recorded as as part of an experiment. In this case both,
337        the stimulus and response will point to the same TimeSeries while the
338        idx_start and count of the invalid column will be set to -1, thus,
339        indicating that no values have been recorded for the stimulus or
340        response, respectively. Note, a recording MUST contain at least a
341        stimulus or a response. Typically the stimulus and response are
342        PatchClampSeries. However, the use of AD/DA channels that are not
343        associated to an electrode is also common in intracellular
344        electrophysiology, in which case other TimeSeries may be used.
345      quantity: '?'
346    - name: simultaneous_recordings
347      neurodata_type_inc: SimultaneousRecordingsTable
348      doc: A table for grouping different intracellular recordings from the
349        IntracellularRecordingsTable table together that were recorded
350        simultaneously from different electrodes
351      quantity: '?'
352    - name: sequential_recordings
353      neurodata_type_inc: SequentialRecordingsTable
354      doc: A table for grouping different sequential recordings from the
355        SimultaneousRecordingsTable table together. This is typically used to
356        group together sequential recordings where the a sequence of stimuli of
357        the same type with varying parameters have been presented in a sequence.
358      quantity: '?'
359    - name: repetitions
360      neurodata_type_inc: RepetitionsTable
361      doc: A table for grouping different sequential intracellular recordings
362        together. With each SequentialRecording typically representing a
363        particular type of stimulus, the RepetitionsTable table is typically
364        used to group sets of stimuli applied in sequence.
365      quantity: '?'
366    - name: experimental_conditions
367      neurodata_type_inc: ExperimentalConditionsTable
368      doc: A table for grouping different intracellular recording repetitions
369        together that belong to the same experimental experimental_conditions.
370      quantity: '?'
371  - name: optogenetics
372    doc: Metadata describing optogenetic stimuluation.
373    quantity: '?'
374    groups:
375    - neurodata_type_inc: OptogeneticStimulusSite
376      doc: An optogenetic stimulation site.
377      quantity: '*'
378  - name: optophysiology
379    doc: Metadata related to optophysiology.
380    quantity: '?'
381    groups:
382    - neurodata_type_inc: ImagingPlane
383      doc: An imaging plane.
384      quantity: '*'
385- name: intervals
386  doc: Experimental intervals, whether that be logically distinct
387    sub-experiments having a particular scientific goal, trials (see trials
388    subgroup) during an experiment, or epochs (see epochs subgroup) deriving
389    from analysis of data.
390  quantity: '?'
391  groups:
392  - name: epochs
393    neurodata_type_inc: TimeIntervals
394    doc: Divisions in time marking experimental stages or sub-divisions of a
395      single recording session.
396    quantity: '?'
397  - name: trials
398    neurodata_type_inc: TimeIntervals
399    doc: Repeated experimental events that have a logical grouping.
400    quantity: '?'
401  - name: invalid_times
402    neurodata_type_inc: TimeIntervals
403    doc: Time intervals that should be removed from analysis.
404    quantity: '?'
405  - neurodata_type_inc: TimeIntervals
406    doc: Optional additional table(s) for describing other experimental time
407      intervals.
408    quantity: '*'
409- name: units
410  neurodata_type_inc: Units
411  doc: Data about sorted spike units.
412  quantity: '?'

3.6.3. LabMetaData

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.5.3

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: LabMetaData
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
3doc: Lab-specific meta-data.

3.6.4. Subject

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.5.4

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: Subject
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 3doc: Information about the animal or person from which the data was measured.
 4datasets:
 5- name: age
 6  dtype: text
 7  doc: Age of subject. Can be supplied instead of 'date_of_birth'.
 8  quantity: '?'
 9  attributes:
10  - name: reference
11    dtype: text
12    default_value: birth
13    doc: Age is with reference to this event. Can be 'birth' or 'gestational'.
14      If reference is omitted, 'birth' is implied.
15    required: false
16- name: date_of_birth
17  dtype: isodatetime
18  doc: Date of birth of subject. Can be supplied instead of 'age'.
19  quantity: '?'
20- name: description
21  dtype: text
22  doc: Description of subject and where subject came from (e.g., breeder, if
23    animal).
24  quantity: '?'
25- name: genotype
26  dtype: text
27  doc: Genetic strain. If absent, assume Wild Type (WT).
28  quantity: '?'
29- name: sex
30  dtype: text
31  doc: Gender of subject.
32  quantity: '?'
33- name: species
34  dtype: text
35  doc: Species of subject.
36  quantity: '?'
37- name: strain
38  dtype: text
39  doc: Strain of subject.
40  quantity: '?'
41- name: subject_id
42  dtype: text
43  doc: ID of animal/person used/participating in experiment (lab convention).
44  quantity: '?'
45- name: weight
46  dtype: text
47  doc: Weight at time of experiment, at time of surgery and at other important
48    times.
49  quantity: '?'

3.7. Miscellaneous neurodata_types.

Miscellaneous types.

3.7.1. AbstractFeatureSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.6.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: AbstractFeatureSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: Abstract features, such as quantitative descriptions of sensory stimuli.
  4  The TimeSeries::data field is a 2D array, storing those features (e.g., for
  5  visual grating stimulus this might be orientation, spatial frequency and
  6  contrast). Null stimuli (eg, uniform gray) can be marked as being an
  7  independent feature (eg, 1.0 for gray, 0.0 for actual stimulus) or by storing
  8  NaNs for feature values, or through use of the TimeSeries::control fields. A
  9  set of features is considered to persist until the next set of features is
 10  defined. The final set of features stored should be the null set. This is
 11  useful when storing the raw stimulus is impractical.
 12attributes:
 13- name: description
 14  dtype: text
 15  default_value: no description
 16  doc: Description of the time series.
 17  required: false
 18- name: comments
 19  dtype: text
 20  default_value: no comments
 21  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 22    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 23    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 24    computer-readable string.
 25  required: false
 26datasets:
 27- name: data
 28  dtype: numeric
 29  dims:
 30  - - num_times
 31  - - num_times
 32    - num_features
 33  shape:
 34  - - null
 35  - - null
 36    - null
 37  doc: Values of each feature at each time.
 38  attributes:
 39  - name: unit
 40    dtype: text
 41    default_value: see 'feature_units'
 42    doc: Since there can be different units for different features, store the
 43      units in 'feature_units'. The default value for this attribute is "see
 44      'feature_units'".
 45    required: false
 46  - name: conversion
 47    dtype: float32
 48    default_value: 1.0
 49    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 50      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 51      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 52      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 53      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 54      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 55      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 56      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 57      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 58    required: false
 59  - name: offset
 60    dtype: float32
 61    default_value: 0.0
 62    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 63      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 64      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 65      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 66      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 67    required: false
 68  - name: resolution
 69    dtype: float32
 70    default_value: -1.0
 71    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 72      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 73      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 74      -1.0.
 75    required: false
 76  - name: continuity
 77    dtype: text
 78    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 79      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 80      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 81      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 82      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 83      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 84      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 85      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 86      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 87    required: false
 88- name: feature_units
 89  dtype: text
 90  dims:
 91  - num_features
 92  shape:
 93  - null
 94  doc: Units of each feature.
 95  quantity: '?'
 96- name: features
 97  dtype: text
 98  dims:
 99  - num_features
100  shape:
101  - null
102  doc: Description of the features represented in TimeSeries::data.
103- name: starting_time
104  dtype: float64
105  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
106    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
107    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
108  quantity: '?'
109  attributes:
110  - name: rate
111    dtype: float32
112    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
113  - name: unit
114    dtype: text
115    value: seconds
116    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
117- name: timestamps
118  dtype: float64
119  dims:
120  - num_times
121  shape:
122  - null
123  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
124    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
125  quantity: '?'
126  attributes:
127  - name: interval
128    dtype: int32
129    value: 1
130    doc: Value is '1'
131  - name: unit
132    dtype: text
133    value: seconds
134    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
135- name: control
136  dtype: uint8
137  dims:
138  - num_times
139  shape:
140  - null
141  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
142    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
143    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
144  quantity: '?'
145- name: control_description
146  dtype: text
147  dims:
148  - num_control_values
149  shape:
150  - null
151  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
152    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
153    == 0.
154  quantity: '?'
155groups:
156- name: sync
157  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
158    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
159    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
160    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
161    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
162    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
163  quantity: '?'

3.7.2. AnnotationSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.6.2

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: AnnotationSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: Stores user annotations made during an experiment. The data[] field stores
  4  a text array, and timestamps are stored for each annotation (ie, interval=1).
  5  This is largely an alias to a standard TimeSeries storing a text array but
  6  that is identifiable as storing annotations in a machine-readable way.
  7attributes:
  8- name: description
  9  dtype: text
 10  default_value: no description
 11  doc: Description of the time series.
 12  required: false
 13- name: comments
 14  dtype: text
 15  default_value: no comments
 16  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 17    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 18    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 19    computer-readable string.
 20  required: false
 21datasets:
 22- name: data
 23  dtype: text
 24  dims:
 25  - num_times
 26  shape:
 27  - null
 28  doc: Annotations made during an experiment.
 29  attributes:
 30  - name: resolution
 31    dtype: float32
 32    value: -1.0
 33    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data. Annotations have
 34      no units, so the value is fixed to -1.0.
 35  - name: unit
 36    dtype: text
 37    value: n/a
 38    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Annotations have no
 39      units, so the value is fixed to 'n/a'.
 40  - name: conversion
 41    dtype: float32
 42    default_value: 1.0
 43    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 44      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 45      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 46      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 47      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 48      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 49      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 50      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 51      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 52    required: false
 53  - name: offset
 54    dtype: float32
 55    default_value: 0.0
 56    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 57      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 58      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 59      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 60      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 61    required: false
 62  - name: continuity
 63    dtype: text
 64    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 65      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 66      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 67      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 68      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 69      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 70      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 71      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 72      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 73    required: false
 74- name: starting_time
 75  dtype: float64
 76  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 77    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 78    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 79  quantity: '?'
 80  attributes:
 81  - name: rate
 82    dtype: float32
 83    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 84  - name: unit
 85    dtype: text
 86    value: seconds
 87    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 88- name: timestamps
 89  dtype: float64
 90  dims:
 91  - num_times
 92  shape:
 93  - null
 94  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
 95    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
 96  quantity: '?'
 97  attributes:
 98  - name: interval
 99    dtype: int32
100    value: 1
101    doc: Value is '1'
102  - name: unit
103    dtype: text
104    value: seconds
105    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
106- name: control
107  dtype: uint8
108  dims:
109  - num_times
110  shape:
111  - null
112  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
113    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
114    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
115  quantity: '?'
116- name: control_description
117  dtype: text
118  dims:
119  - num_control_values
120  shape:
121  - null
122  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
123    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
124    == 0.
125  quantity: '?'
126groups:
127- name: sync
128  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
129    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
130    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
131    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
132    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
133    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
134  quantity: '?'

3.7.3. IntervalSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.6.3

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: IntervalSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: Stores intervals of data. The timestamps field stores the beginning and end
  4  of intervals. The data field stores whether the interval just started (>0
  5  value) or ended (<0 value). Different interval types can be represented in the
  6  same series by using multiple key values (eg, 1 for feature A, 2 for feature
  7  B, 3 for feature C, etc). The field data stores an 8-bit integer. This is
  8  largely an alias of a standard TimeSeries but that is identifiable as
  9  representing time intervals in a machine-readable way.
 10attributes:
 11- name: description
 12  dtype: text
 13  default_value: no description
 14  doc: Description of the time series.
 15  required: false
 16- name: comments
 17  dtype: text
 18  default_value: no comments
 19  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 20    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 21    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 22    computer-readable string.
 23  required: false
 24datasets:
 25- name: data
 26  dtype: int8
 27  dims:
 28  - num_times
 29  shape:
 30  - null
 31  doc: Use values >0 if interval started, <0 if interval ended.
 32  attributes:
 33  - name: resolution
 34    dtype: float32
 35    value: -1.0
 36    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data. Annotations have
 37      no units, so the value is fixed to -1.0.
 38  - name: unit
 39    dtype: text
 40    value: n/a
 41    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Annotations have no
 42      units, so the value is fixed to 'n/a'.
 43  - name: conversion
 44    dtype: float32
 45    default_value: 1.0
 46    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 47      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 48      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 49      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 50      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 51      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 52      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 53      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 54      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 55    required: false
 56  - name: offset
 57    dtype: float32
 58    default_value: 0.0
 59    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 60      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 61      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 62      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 63      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 64    required: false
 65  - name: continuity
 66    dtype: text
 67    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 68      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 69      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 70      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 71      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 72      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 73      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 74      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 75      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 76    required: false
 77- name: starting_time
 78  dtype: float64
 79  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 80    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 81    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 82  quantity: '?'
 83  attributes:
 84  - name: rate
 85    dtype: float32
 86    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 87  - name: unit
 88    dtype: text
 89    value: seconds
 90    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 91- name: timestamps
 92  dtype: float64
 93  dims:
 94  - num_times
 95  shape:
 96  - null
 97  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
 98    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
 99  quantity: '?'
100  attributes:
101  - name: interval
102    dtype: int32
103    value: 1
104    doc: Value is '1'
105  - name: unit
106    dtype: text
107    value: seconds
108    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
109- name: control
110  dtype: uint8
111  dims:
112  - num_times
113  shape:
114  - null
115  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
116    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
117    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
118  quantity: '?'
119- name: control_description
120  dtype: text
121  dims:
122  - num_control_values
123  shape:
124  - null
125  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
126    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
127    == 0.
128  quantity: '?'
129groups:
130- name: sync
131  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
132    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
133    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
134    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
135    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
136    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
137  quantity: '?'

3.7.4. FrequencyBandsTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.6.4

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: FrequencyBandsTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3doc: Table for describing the bands that DecompositionSeries was generated from.
 4  There should be one row in this table for each band.
 5attributes:
 6- name: colnames
 7  dtype: text
 8  dims:
 9  - num_columns
10  shape:
11  - null
12  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
13    order to the columns.
14- name: description
15  dtype: text
16  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
17datasets:
18- name: band_name
19  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
20  dtype: text
21  doc: Name of the band, e.g. theta.
22- name: band_limits
23  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
24  dtype: float32
25  dims:
26  - num_bands
27  - low, high
28  shape:
29  - null
30  - 2
31  doc: Low and high limit of each band in Hz. If it is a Gaussian filter, use 2
32    SD on either side of the center.
33- name: band_mean
34  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
35  dtype: float32
36  dims:
37  - num_bands
38  shape:
39  - null
40  doc: The mean Gaussian filters, in Hz.
41  quantity: '?'
42- name: band_stdev
43  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
44  dtype: float32
45  dims:
46  - num_bands
47  shape:
48  - null
49  doc: The standard deviation of Gaussian filters, in Hz.
50  quantity: '?'
51- name: id
52  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
53  dtype: int
54  dims:
55  - num_rows
56  shape:
57  - null
58  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
59- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
60  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
61  quantity: '*'

3.7.5. DecompositionSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.6.5

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: DecompositionSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: Spectral analysis of a time series, e.g. of an LFP or a speech signal.
  4attributes:
  5- name: description
  6  dtype: text
  7  default_value: no description
  8  doc: Description of the time series.
  9  required: false
 10- name: comments
 11  dtype: text
 12  default_value: no comments
 13  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 14    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 15    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 16    computer-readable string.
 17  required: false
 18datasets:
 19- name: data
 20  dtype: numeric
 21  dims:
 22  - num_times
 23  - num_channels
 24  - num_bands
 25  shape:
 26  - null
 27  - null
 28  - null
 29  doc: Data decomposed into frequency bands.
 30  attributes:
 31  - name: unit
 32    dtype: text
 33    default_value: no unit
 34    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 35      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 36      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion'.
 37    required: false
 38  - name: conversion
 39    dtype: float32
 40    default_value: 1.0
 41    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 42      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 43      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 44      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 45      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 46      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 47      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 48      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 49      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 50    required: false
 51  - name: offset
 52    dtype: float32
 53    default_value: 0.0
 54    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 55      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 56      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 57      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 58      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 59    required: false
 60  - name: resolution
 61    dtype: float32
 62    default_value: -1.0
 63    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 64      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 65      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 66      -1.0.
 67    required: false
 68  - name: continuity
 69    dtype: text
 70    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 71      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 72      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 73      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 74      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
