 75      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 76      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 77      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 78      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 79    required: false
 80- name: metric
 81  dtype: text
 82  doc: The metric used, e.g. phase, amplitude, power.
 83- name: source_channels
 84  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
 85  doc: DynamicTableRegion pointer to the channels that this decomposition series
 86    was generated from.
 87  quantity: '?'
 88- name: starting_time
 89  dtype: float64
 90  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 91    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 92    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 93  quantity: '?'
 94  attributes:
 95  - name: rate
 96    dtype: float32
 97    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 98  - name: unit
 99    dtype: text
100    value: seconds
101    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
102- name: timestamps
103  dtype: float64
104  dims:
105  - num_times
106  shape:
107  - null
108  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
109    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
110  quantity: '?'
111  attributes:
112  - name: interval
113    dtype: int32
114    value: 1
115    doc: Value is '1'
116  - name: unit
117    dtype: text
118    value: seconds
119    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
120- name: control
121  dtype: uint8
122  dims:
123  - num_times
124  shape:
125  - null
126  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
127    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
128    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
129  quantity: '?'
130- name: control_description
131  dtype: text
132  dims:
133  - num_control_values
134  shape:
135  - null
136  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
137    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
138    == 0.
139  quantity: '?'
140groups:
141- name: bands
142  neurodata_type_inc: FrequencyBandsTable
143  doc: Table for describing the bands that this series was generated from.
144  quantity: '?'
145- name: sync
146  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
147    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
148    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
149    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
150    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
151    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
152  quantity: '?'
153links:
154- name: source_timeseries
155  target_type: TimeSeries
156  doc: Link to TimeSeries object that this data was calculated from. Metadata
157    about electrodes and their position can be read from that ElectricalSeries
158    so it is not necessary to store that information here.
159  quantity: '?'

3.7.6. Units

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.6.6

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: Units
  2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
  3default_name: Units
  4doc: Data about spiking units. Event times of observed units (e.g. cell,
  5  synapse, etc.) should be concatenated and stored in spike_times.
  6attributes:
  7- name: colnames
  8  dtype: text
  9  dims:
 10  - num_columns
 11  shape:
 12  - null
 13  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
 14    order to the columns.
 15- name: description
 16  dtype: text
 17  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
 18datasets:
 19- name: spike_times_index
 20  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
 21  doc: Index into the spike_times dataset.
 22  quantity: '?'
 23- name: spike_times
 24  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 25  dtype: float64
 26  doc: Spike times for each unit in seconds.
 27  quantity: '?'
 28  attributes:
 29  - name: resolution
 30    dtype: float64
 31    doc: The smallest possible difference between two spike times. Usually 1
 32      divided by the acquisition sampling rate from which spike times were
 33      extracted, but could be larger if the acquisition time series was
 34      downsampled or smaller if the acquisition time series was
 35      smoothed/interpolated and it is possible for the spike time to be between
 36      samples.
 37    required: false
 38- name: obs_intervals_index
 39  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
 40  doc: Index into the obs_intervals dataset.
 41  quantity: '?'
 42- name: obs_intervals
 43  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 44  dtype: float64
 45  dims:
 46  - num_intervals
 47  - start|end
 48  shape:
 49  - null
 50  - 2
 51  doc: Observation intervals for each unit.
 52  quantity: '?'
 53- name: electrodes_index
 54  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
 55  doc: Index into electrodes.
 56  quantity: '?'
 57- name: electrodes
 58  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
 59  doc: Electrode that each spike unit came from, specified using a
 60    DynamicTableRegion.
 61  quantity: '?'
 62- name: electrode_group
 63  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 64  dtype:
 65    target_type: ElectrodeGroup
 66    reftype: object
 67  doc: Electrode group that each spike unit came from.
 68  quantity: '?'
 69- name: waveform_mean
 70  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 71  dtype: float32
 72  dims:
 73  - - num_units
 74    - num_samples
 75  - - num_units
 76    - num_samples
 77    - num_electrodes
 78  shape:
 79  - - null
 80    - null
 81  - - null
 82    - null
 83    - null
 84  doc: Spike waveform mean for each spike unit.
 85  quantity: '?'
 86  attributes:
 87  - name: sampling_rate
 88    dtype: float32
 89    doc: Sampling rate, in hertz.
 90    required: false
 91  - name: unit
 92    dtype: text
 93    value: volts
 94    doc: Unit of measurement. This value is fixed to 'volts'.
 95- name: waveform_sd
 96  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 97  dtype: float32
 98  dims:
 99  - - num_units
100    - num_samples
101  - - num_units
102    - num_samples
103    - num_electrodes
104  shape:
105  - - null
106    - null
107  - - null
108    - null
109    - null
110  doc: Spike waveform standard deviation for each spike unit.
111  quantity: '?'
112  attributes:
113  - name: sampling_rate
114    dtype: float32
115    doc: Sampling rate, in hertz.
116    required: false
117  - name: unit
118    dtype: text
119    value: volts
120    doc: Unit of measurement. This value is fixed to 'volts'.
121- name: waveforms
122  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
123  dtype: numeric
124  dims:
125  - num_waveforms
126  - num_samples
127  shape:
128  - null
129  - null
130  doc: Individual waveforms for each spike on each electrode. This is a doubly
131    indexed column. The 'waveforms_index' column indexes which waveforms in this
132    column belong to the same spike event for a given unit, where each waveform
133    was recorded from a different electrode. The 'waveforms_index_index' column
134    indexes the 'waveforms_index' column to indicate which spike events belong
135    to a given unit. For example, if the 'waveforms_index_index' column has
136    values [2, 5, 6], then the first 2 elements of the 'waveforms_index' column
137    correspond to the 2 spike events of the first unit, the next 3 elements of
138    the 'waveforms_index' column correspond to the 3 spike events of the second
139    unit, and the next 1 element of the 'waveforms_index' column corresponds to
140    the 1 spike event of the third unit. If the 'waveforms_index' column has
141    values [3, 6, 8, 10, 12, 13], then the first 3 elements of the 'waveforms'
142    column contain the 3 spike waveforms that were recorded from 3 different
143    electrodes for the first spike time of the first unit. See
144    https://nwb-schema.readthedocs.io/en/stable/format_description.html#doubly-ragged-arrays
145    for a graphical representation of this example. When there is only one
146    electrode for each unit (i.e., each spike time is associated with a single
147    waveform), then the 'waveforms_index' column will have values 1, 2, ..., N,
148    where N is the number of spike events. The number of electrodes for each
149    spike event should be the same within a given unit. The 'electrodes' column
150    should be used to indicate which electrodes are associated with each unit,
151    and the order of the waveforms within a given unit x spike event should be
152    the same as the order of the electrodes referenced in the 'electrodes'
153    column of this table. The number of samples for each waveform must be the
154    same.
155  quantity: '?'
156  attributes:
157  - name: sampling_rate
158    dtype: float32
159    doc: Sampling rate, in hertz.
160    required: false
161  - name: unit
162    dtype: text
163    value: volts
164    doc: Unit of measurement. This value is fixed to 'volts'.
165- name: waveforms_index
166  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
167  doc: Index into the 'waveforms' dataset. One value for every spike event. See
168    'waveforms' for more detail.
169  quantity: '?'
170- name: waveforms_index_index
171  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
172  doc: Index into the 'waveforms_index' dataset. One value for every unit (row
173    in the table). See 'waveforms' for more detail.
174  quantity: '?'
175- name: id
176  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
177  dtype: int
178  dims:
179  - num_rows
180  shape:
181  - null
182  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
183- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
184  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
185  quantity: '*'

3.8. Behavior

This source module contains neurodata_types for behavior data.

3.8.1. SpatialSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.7.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: SpatialSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: "Direction, e.g., of gaze or travel, or position. The TimeSeries::data field
  4  is a 2D array storing position or direction relative to some reference frame. Array
  5  structure: [num measurements] [num dimensions]. Each SpatialSeries has a text dataset
  6  reference_frame that indicates the zero-position, or the zero-axes for direction.
  7  For example, if representing gaze direction, 'straight-ahead' might be a specific
  8  pixel on the monitor, or some other point in space. For position data, the 0,0 point
  9  might be the top-left corner of an enclosure, as viewed from the tracking camera.
 10  The unit of data will indicate how to interpret SpatialSeries values."
 11attributes:
 12- name: description
 13  dtype: text
 14  default_value: no description
 15  doc: Description of the time series.
 16  required: false
 17- name: comments
 18  dtype: text
 19  default_value: no comments
 20  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 21    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 22    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 23    computer-readable string.
 24  required: false
 25datasets:
 26- name: data
 27  dtype: numeric
 28  dims:
 29  - - num_times
 30  - - num_times
 31    - x
 32  - - num_times
 33    - x,y
 34  - - num_times
 35    - x,y,z
 36  shape:
 37  - - null
 38  - - null
 39    - 1
 40  - - null
 41    - 2
 42  - - null
 43    - 3
 44  doc: 1-D or 2-D array storing position or direction relative to some reference
 45    frame.
 46  attributes:
 47  - name: unit
 48    dtype: text
 49    default_value: meters
 50    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. The default value
 51      is 'meters'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these
 52      units. To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion'
 53      and add 'offset'.
 54    required: false
 55  - name: conversion
 56    dtype: float32
 57    default_value: 1.0
 58    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 59      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 60      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 61      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 62      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 63      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 64      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 65      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 66      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 67    required: false
 68  - name: offset
 69    dtype: float32
 70    default_value: 0.0
 71    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 72      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 73      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 74      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 75      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 76    required: false
 77  - name: resolution
 78    dtype: float32
 79    default_value: -1.0
 80    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 81      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 82      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 83      -1.0.
 84    required: false
 85  - name: continuity
 86    dtype: text
 87    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 88      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 89      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 90      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 91      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 92      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 93      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 94      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 95      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 96    required: false
 97- name: reference_frame
 98  dtype: text
 99  doc: Description defining what exactly 'straight-ahead' means.
100  quantity: '?'
101- name: starting_time
102  dtype: float64
103  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
104    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
105    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
106  quantity: '?'
107  attributes:
108  - name: rate
109    dtype: float32
110    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
111  - name: unit
112    dtype: text
113    value: seconds
114    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
115- name: timestamps
116  dtype: float64
117  dims:
118  - num_times
119  shape:
120  - null
121  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
122    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
123  quantity: '?'
124  attributes:
125  - name: interval
126    dtype: int32
127    value: 1
128    doc: Value is '1'
129  - name: unit
130    dtype: text
131    value: seconds
132    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
133- name: control
134  dtype: uint8
135  dims:
136  - num_times
137  shape:
138  - null
139  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
140    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
141    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
142  quantity: '?'
143- name: control_description
144  dtype: text
145  dims:
146  - num_control_values
147  shape:
148  - null
149  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
150    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
151    == 0.
152  quantity: '?'
153groups:
154- name: sync
155  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
156    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
157    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
158    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
159    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
160    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
161  quantity: '?'

3.8.2. BehavioralEpochs

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.2

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: BehavioralEpochs
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: BehavioralEpochs
 4doc: TimeSeries for storing behavioral epochs.  The objective of this and the
 5  other two Behavioral interfaces (e.g. BehavioralEvents and
 6  BehavioralTimeSeries) is to provide generic hooks for software tools/scripts.
 7  This allows a tool/script to take the output one specific interface (e.g.,
 8  UnitTimes) and plot that data relative to another data modality (e.g.,
 9  behavioral events) without having to define all possible modalities in
10  advance. Declaring one of these interfaces means that one or more TimeSeries
11  of the specified type is published. These TimeSeries should reside in a group
12  having the same name as the interface. For example, if a BehavioralTimeSeries
13  interface is declared, the module will have one or more TimeSeries defined in
14  the module sub-group 'BehavioralTimeSeries'. BehavioralEpochs should use
15  IntervalSeries. BehavioralEvents is used for irregular events.
16  BehavioralTimeSeries is for continuous data.
17groups:
18- neurodata_type_inc: IntervalSeries
19  doc: IntervalSeries object containing start and stop times of epochs.
20  quantity: +

3.8.3. BehavioralEvents

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.3

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: BehavioralEvents
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
3default_name: BehavioralEvents
4doc: TimeSeries for storing behavioral events. See description of
5  BehavioralEpochs for more details.
6groups:
7- neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
8  doc: TimeSeries object containing behavioral events.
9  quantity: +

3.8.4. BehavioralTimeSeries

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.4

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: BehavioralTimeSeries
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
3default_name: BehavioralTimeSeries
4doc: TimeSeries for storing behavioral time series data. See description of
5  BehavioralEpochs for more details.
6groups:
7- neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
8  doc: TimeSeries object containing continuous behavioral data.
9  quantity: +

3.8.5. PupilTracking

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.5

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: PupilTracking
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
3default_name: PupilTracking
4doc: Eye-tracking data, representing pupil size.
5groups:
6- neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
7  doc: TimeSeries object containing time series data on pupil size.
8  quantity: +

3.8.6. EyeTracking

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.6

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: EyeTracking
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
3default_name: EyeTracking
4doc: Eye-tracking data, representing direction of gaze.
5groups:
6- neurodata_type_inc: SpatialSeries
7  doc: SpatialSeries object containing data measuring direction of gaze.
8  quantity: +

3.8.7. CompassDirection

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.7

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: CompassDirection
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: CompassDirection
 4doc: With a CompassDirection interface, a module publishes a SpatialSeries
 5  object representing a floating point value for theta. The
 6  SpatialSeries::reference_frame field should indicate what direction
 7  corresponds to 0 and which is the direction of rotation (this should be
 8  clockwise). The si_unit for the SpatialSeries should be radians or degrees.
 9groups:
10- neurodata_type_inc: SpatialSeries
11  doc: SpatialSeries object containing direction of gaze travel.
12  quantity: +

3.8.8. Position

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.7.8

YAML Specification:

1neurodata_type_def: Position
2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
3default_name: Position
4doc: Position data, whether along the x, x/y or x/y/z axis.
5groups:
6- neurodata_type_inc: SpatialSeries
7  doc: SpatialSeries object containing position data.
8  quantity: +

3.9. Extracellular electrophysiology

This source module contains neurodata_types for extracellular electrophysiology data.

3.9.1. ElectricalSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.8.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: ElectricalSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: A time series of acquired voltage data from extracellular recordings. The
  4  data field is an int or float array storing data in volts. The first dimension
  5  should always represent time. The second dimension, if present, should
  6  represent channels.
  7attributes:
  8- name: filtering
  9  dtype: text
 10  doc: Filtering applied to all channels of the data. For example, if this
 11    ElectricalSeries represents high-pass-filtered data (also known as AP Band),
 12    then this value could be "High-pass 4-pole Bessel filter at 500 Hz". If this
 13    ElectricalSeries represents low-pass-filtered LFP data and the type of
 14    filter is unknown, then this value could be "Low-pass filter at 300 Hz". If
 15    a non-standard filter type is used, provide as much detail about the filter
 16    properties as possible.
 17  required: false
 18- name: description
 19  dtype: text
 20  default_value: no description
 21  doc: Description of the time series.
 22  required: false
 23- name: comments
 24  dtype: text
 25  default_value: no comments
 26  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 27    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 28    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 29    computer-readable string.
 30  required: false
 31datasets:
 32- name: data
 33  dtype: numeric
 34  dims:
 35  - - num_times
 36  - - num_times
 37    - num_channels
 38  - - num_times
 39    - num_channels
 40    - num_samples
 41  shape:
 42  - - null
 43  - - null
 44    - null
 45  - - null
 46    - null
 47    - null
 48  doc: Recorded voltage data.
 49  attributes:
 50  - name: unit
 51    dtype: text
 52    value: volts
 53    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. This value is fixed
 54      to 'volts'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these
 55      units. To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion',
 56      followed by 'channel_conversion' (if present), and then add 'offset'.
 57  - name: conversion
 58    dtype: float32
 59    default_value: 1.0
 60    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 61      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 62      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 63      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 64      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 65      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 66      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 67      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 68      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 69    required: false
 70  - name: offset
 71    dtype: float32
 72    default_value: 0.0
 73    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 74      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 75      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 76      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 77      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 78    required: false
 79  - name: resolution
 80    dtype: float32
 81    default_value: -1.0
 82    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 83      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 84      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 85      -1.0.
 86    required: false
 87  - name: continuity
 88    dtype: text
 89    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 90      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 91      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 92      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 93      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 94      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 95      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 96      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 97      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 98    required: false
 99- name: electrodes
100  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
101  doc: DynamicTableRegion pointer to the electrodes that this time series was
102    generated from.
103- name: channel_conversion
104  dtype: float32
105  dims:
106  - num_channels
107  shape:
108  - null
109  doc: Channel-specific conversion factor. Multiply the data in the 'data'
110    dataset by these values along the channel axis (as indicated by axis
111    attribute) AND by the global conversion factor in the 'conversion' attribute
112    of 'data' to get the data values in Volts, i.e, data in Volts = data *
113    data.conversion * channel_conversion. This approach allows for both global
114    and per-channel data conversion factors needed to support the storage of
115    electrical recordings as native values generated by data acquisition
116    systems. If this dataset is not present, then there is no channel-specific
117    conversion factor, i.e. it is 1 for all channels.
118  quantity: '?'
119  attributes:
120  - name: axis
121    dtype: int32
122    value: 1
123    doc: The zero-indexed axis of the 'data' dataset that the channel-specific
124      conversion factor corresponds to. This value is fixed to 1.
125- name: starting_time
126  dtype: float64
127  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
128    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
129    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
130  quantity: '?'
131  attributes:
132  - name: rate
133    dtype: float32
134    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
135  - name: unit
136    dtype: text
137    value: seconds
138    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
139- name: timestamps
140  dtype: float64
141  dims:
142  - num_times
143  shape:
144  - null
145  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
146    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
147  quantity: '?'
148  attributes:
149  - name: interval
150    dtype: int32
151    value: 1
152    doc: Value is '1'
153  - name: unit
154    dtype: text
155    value: seconds
156    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
157- name: control
158  dtype: uint8
159  dims:
160  - num_times
161  shape:
162  - null
163  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
164    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
165    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
166  quantity: '?'
167- name: control_description
168  dtype: text
169  dims:
170  - num_control_values
171  shape:
172  - null
173  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
174    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
175    == 0.
176  quantity: '?'
177groups:
178- name: sync
179  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
180    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
181    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
182    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
183    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
184    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
185  quantity: '?'

3.9.2. SpikeEventSeries

Extends: ElectricalSeries

Description: see Section 2.8.2

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: SpikeEventSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: ElectricalSeries
  3doc: 'Stores snapshots/snippets of recorded spike events (i.e., threshold crossings).
  4  This may also be raw data, as reported by ephys hardware. If so, the TimeSeries::description
  5  field should describe how events were detected. All events span the same recording
  6  channels and store snapshots of equal duration. TimeSeries::data array structure:
  7  [num events] [num channels] [num samples] (or [num events] [num samples] for single
  8  electrode).'
  9attributes:
 10- name: filtering
 11  dtype: text
 12  doc: Filtering applied to all channels of the data. For example, if this
 13    ElectricalSeries represents high-pass-filtered data (also known as AP Band),
 14    then this value could be "High-pass 4-pole Bessel filter at 500 Hz". If this
 15    ElectricalSeries represents low-pass-filtered LFP data and the type of
 16    filter is unknown, then this value could be "Low-pass filter at 300 Hz". If
 17    a non-standard filter type is used, provide as much detail about the filter
 18    properties as possible.
 19  required: false
 20- name: description
 21  dtype: text
 22  default_value: no description
 23  doc: Description of the time series.
 24  required: false
 25- name: comments
 26  dtype: text
 27  default_value: no comments
 28  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 29    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 30    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 31    computer-readable string.
 32  required: false
 33datasets:
 34- name: data
 35  dtype: numeric
 36  dims:
 37  - - num_events
 38    - num_samples
 39  - - num_events
 40    - num_channels
 41    - num_samples
 42  shape:
 43  - - null
 44    - null
 45  - - null
 46    - null
 47    - null
 48  doc: Spike waveforms.
 49  attributes:
 50  - name: unit
 51    dtype: text
 52    value: volts
 53    doc: Unit of measurement for waveforms, which is fixed to 'volts'.
 54  - name: conversion
 55    dtype: float32
 56    default_value: 1.0
 57    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 58      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 59      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 60      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 61      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 62      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 63      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 64      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 65      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 66    required: false
 67  - name: offset
 68    dtype: float32
 69    default_value: 0.0
 70    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 71      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 72      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 73      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 74      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 75    required: false
 76  - name: resolution
 77    dtype: float32
 78    default_value: -1.0
 79    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 80      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 81      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 82      -1.0.
 83    required: false
 84  - name: continuity
 85    dtype: text
 86    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 87      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 88      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 89      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 90      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 91      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 92      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 93      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 94      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 95    required: false
 96- name: timestamps
 97  dtype: float64
 98  dims:
 99  - num_times
100  shape:
101  - null
102  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
103    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
104    Timestamps are required for the events. Unlike for TimeSeries, timestamps
105    are required for SpikeEventSeries and are thus re-specified here.
106  attributes:
107  - name: interval
108    dtype: int32
109    value: 1
110    doc: Value is '1'
111  - name: unit
112    dtype: text
113    value: seconds
114    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
115- name: electrodes
116  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
117  doc: DynamicTableRegion pointer to the electrodes that this time series was
118    generated from.
119- name: channel_conversion
120  dtype: float32
121  dims:
122  - num_channels
123  shape:
124  - null
125  doc: Channel-specific conversion factor. Multiply the data in the 'data'
126    dataset by these values along the channel axis (as indicated by axis
127    attribute) AND by the global conversion factor in the 'conversion' attribute
128    of 'data' to get the data values in Volts, i.e, data in Volts = data *
129    data.conversion * channel_conversion. This approach allows for both global
130    and per-channel data conversion factors needed to support the storage of
131    electrical recordings as native values generated by data acquisition
132    systems. If this dataset is not present, then there is no channel-specific
133    conversion factor, i.e. it is 1 for all channels.
134  quantity: '?'
135  attributes:
136  - name: axis
137    dtype: int32
138    value: 1
139    doc: The zero-indexed axis of the 'data' dataset that the channel-specific
140      conversion factor corresponds to. This value is fixed to 1.
141- name: starting_time
142  dtype: float64
143  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
144    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
145    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
146  quantity: '?'
147  attributes:
148  - name: rate
149    dtype: float32
150    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
151  - name: unit
152    dtype: text
153    value: seconds
154    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
155- name: control
156  dtype: uint8
157  dims:
158  - num_times
159  shape:
160  - null
161  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
162    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
163    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
164  quantity: '?'
165- name: control_description
166  dtype: text
167  dims:
168  - num_control_values
169  shape:
170  - null
171  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
172    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
173    == 0.
174  quantity: '?'
175groups:
176- name: sync
177  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
178    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
179    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
180    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
181    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
182    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
183  quantity: '?'

3.9.3. FeatureExtraction

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.3

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: FeatureExtraction
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: FeatureExtraction
 4doc: Features, such as PC1 and PC2, that are extracted from signals stored in a
 5  SpikeEventSeries or other source.
 6datasets:
 7- name: description
 8  dtype: text
 9  dims:
10  - num_features
11  shape:
12  - null
13  doc: Description of features (eg, ''PC1'') for each of the extracted features.
14- name: features
15  dtype: float32
16  dims:
17  - num_events
18  - num_channels
19  - num_features
20  shape:
21  - null
22  - null
23  - null
24  doc: Multi-dimensional array of features extracted from each event.
25- name: times
26  dtype: float64
27  dims:
28  - num_events
29  shape:
30  - null
31  doc: Times of events that features correspond to (can be a link).
32- name: electrodes
33  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
34  doc: DynamicTableRegion pointer to the electrodes that this time series was
35    generated from.

3.9.4. EventDetection

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.4

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: EventDetection
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: EventDetection
 4doc: Detected spike events from voltage trace(s).
 5datasets:
 6- name: detection_method
 7  dtype: text
 8  doc: Description of how events were detected, such as voltage threshold, or
 9    dV/dT threshold, as well as relevant values.
10- name: source_idx
11  dtype: int32
12  dims:
13  - - num_events
14  - - num_events
15    - time_index, channel_index
16  shape:
17  - - null
18  - - null
19    - 2
20  doc: Indices (zero-based) into the linked source ElectricalSeries::data array
21    corresponding to time of event or time and channel of event. ''description''
22    should define what is meant by time of event (e.g., .25 ms before action
23    potential peak, zero-crossing time, etc). The index points to each event
24    from the raw data.
25- name: times
26  dtype: float64
27  dims:
28  - num_events
29  shape:
30  - null
31  doc: DEPRECATED. Timestamps of events, in seconds.
32  quantity: '?'
33  attributes:
34  - name: unit
35    dtype: text
36    value: seconds
37    doc: Unit of measurement for event times, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
38links:
39- name: source_electricalseries
40  target_type: ElectricalSeries
41  doc: Link to the ElectricalSeries that this data was calculated from. Metadata
42    about electrodes and their position can be read from that ElectricalSeries
43    so it's not necessary to include that information here.

3.9.5. EventWaveform

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.5

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: EventWaveform
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: EventWaveform
 4doc: DEPRECATED. Represents either the waveforms of detected events, as
 5  extracted from a raw data trace in /acquisition, or the event waveforms that
 6  were stored during experiment acquisition.
 7groups:
 8- neurodata_type_inc: SpikeEventSeries
 9  doc: SpikeEventSeries object(s) containing detected spike event waveforms.
10  quantity: +

3.9.6. FilteredEphys

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.6

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: FilteredEphys
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: FilteredEphys
 4doc: Electrophysiology data from one or more channels that has been subjected to
 5  filtering. Examples of filtered data include Theta and Gamma (LFP has its own
 6  interface). FilteredEphys modules publish an ElectricalSeries for each
 7  filtered channel or set of channels. The name of each ElectricalSeries is
 8  arbitrary but should be informative. The source of the filtered data, whether
 9  this is from analysis of another time series or as acquired by hardware,
10  should be noted in each's TimeSeries::description field. There is no assumed
11  1::1 correspondence between filtered ephys signals and electrodes, as a single
12  signal can apply to many nearby electrodes, and one electrode may have
13  different filtered (e.g., theta and/or gamma) signals represented. Filter
14  properties should be noted in the ElectricalSeries 'filtering' attribute.
15groups:
16- neurodata_type_inc: ElectricalSeries
17  doc: ElectricalSeries object(s) containing filtered electrophysiology data.
18  quantity: +

3.9.7. LFP

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.7

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: LFP
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: LFP
 4doc: LFP data from one or more channels. The electrode map in each published
 5  ElectricalSeries will identify which channels are providing LFP data. Filter
 6  properties should be noted in the ElectricalSeries 'filtering' attribute.
 7groups:
 8- neurodata_type_inc: ElectricalSeries
 9  doc: ElectricalSeries object(s) containing LFP data for one or more channels.
10  quantity: +

3.9.8. ElectrodeGroup

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.8.8

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: ElectrodeGroup
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 3doc: A physical grouping of electrodes, e.g. a shank of an array.
 4attributes:
 5- name: description
 6  dtype: text
 7  doc: Description of this electrode group.
 8- name: location
 9  dtype: text
10  doc: Location of electrode group. Specify the area, layer, comments on
11    estimation of area/layer, etc. Use standard atlas names for anatomical
12    regions when possible.
13datasets:
14- name: position
15  dtype:
16  - name: x
17    dtype: float32
18    doc: x coordinate
19  - name: y
20    dtype: float32
21    doc: y coordinate
22  - name: z
23    dtype: float32
24    doc: z coordinate
25  doc: stereotaxic or common framework coordinates
26  quantity: '?'
27links:
28- name: device
29  target_type: Device
30  doc: Link to the device that was used to record from this electrode group.

3.9.9. ElectrodesTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.8.9

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: ElectrodesTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3doc: A table of all electrodes (i.e. channels) used for recording. Introduced in
 4  NWB 2.8.0. Replaces the "electrodes" table (neurodata_type_inc DynamicTable,
 5  no neurodata_type_def) that is part of NWBFile.
 6attributes:
 7- name: colnames
 8  dtype: text
 9  dims:
10  - num_columns
11  shape:
12  - null
13  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
14    order to the columns.
15- name: description
16  dtype: text
17  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
18datasets:
19- name: location
20  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
21  dtype: text
22  doc: Location of the electrode (channel). Specify the area, layer, comments on
23    estimation of area/layer, stereotaxic coordinates if in vivo, etc. Use
24    standard atlas names for anatomical regions when possible.
25- name: group
26  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
27  dtype:
28    target_type: ElectrodeGroup
29    reftype: object
30  doc: Reference to the ElectrodeGroup this electrode is a part of.
31- name: group_name
32  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
33  dtype: text
34  doc: Name of the ElectrodeGroup this electrode is a part of.
35  quantity: '?'
36- name: x
37  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
38  dtype: float32
39  doc: x coordinate of the channel location in the brain (+x is posterior).
40  quantity: '?'
41- name: y
42  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
43  dtype: float32
44  doc: y coordinate of the channel location in the brain (+y is inferior).
45  quantity: '?'
46- name: z
47  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
48  dtype: float32
49  doc: z coordinate of the channel location in the brain (+z is right).
50  quantity: '?'
51- name: imp
52  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
53  dtype: float32
54  doc: Impedance of the channel, in ohms.
55  quantity: '?'
56- name: filtering
57  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
58  dtype: text
59  doc: Description of hardware filtering, including the filter name and
60    frequency cutoffs.
61  quantity: '?'
62- name: rel_x
63  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
64  dtype: float32
65  doc: x coordinate in electrode group
66  quantity: '?'
67- name: rel_y
68  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
69  dtype: float32
70  doc: y coordinate in electrode group
71  quantity: '?'
72- name: rel_z
73  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
74  dtype: float32
75  doc: z coordinate in electrode group
76  quantity: '?'
77- name: reference
78  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
79  dtype: text
80  doc: Description of the reference electrode and/or reference scheme used for
81    this electrode, e.g., "stainless steel skull screw" or "online common
82    average referencing".
83  quantity: '?'
84- name: id
85  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
86  dtype: int
87  dims:
88  - num_rows
89  shape:
90  - null
91  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
92- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
93  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
94  quantity: '*'

3.9.10. ClusterWaveforms

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.10

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: ClusterWaveforms
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: ClusterWaveforms
 4doc: DEPRECATED The mean waveform shape, including standard deviation, of the
 5  different clusters. Ideally, the waveform analysis should be performed on data
 6  that is only high-pass filtered. This is a separate module because it is
 7  expected to require updating. For example, IMEC probes may require different
 8  storage requirements to store/display mean waveforms, requiring a new
 9  interface or an extension of this one.
10datasets:
11- name: waveform_filtering
12  dtype: text
13  doc: Filtering applied to data before generating mean/sd
14- name: waveform_mean
15  dtype: float32
16  dims:
17  - num_clusters
18  - num_samples
19  shape:
20  - null
21  - null
22  doc: The mean waveform for each cluster, using the same indices for each wave
23    as cluster numbers in the associated Clustering module (i.e, cluster 3 is in
24    array slot [3]). Waveforms corresponding to gaps in cluster sequence should
25    be empty (e.g., zero- filled)
26- name: waveform_sd
27  dtype: float32
28  dims:
29  - num_clusters
30  - num_samples
31  shape:
32  - null
33  - null
34  doc: Stdev of waveforms for each cluster, using the same indices as in mean
35links:
36- name: clustering_interface
37  target_type: Clustering
38  doc: Link to Clustering interface that was the source of the clustered data

3.9.11. Clustering

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.8.11

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: Clustering
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: Clustering
 4doc: DEPRECATED Clustered spike data, whether from automatic clustering tools
 5  (e.g., klustakwik) or as a result of manual sorting.
 6datasets:
 7- name: description
 8  dtype: text
 9  doc: Description of clusters or clustering, (e.g. cluster 0 is noise, clusters
10    curated using Klusters, etc)
11- name: num
12  dtype: int32
13  dims:
14  - num_events
15  shape:
16  - null
17  doc: Cluster number of each event
18- name: peak_over_rms
19  dtype: float32
20  dims:
21  - num_clusters
22  shape:
23  - null
24  doc: Maximum ratio of waveform peak to RMS on any channel in the cluster
25    (provides a basic clustering metric).
26- name: times
27  dtype: float64
28  dims:
29  - num_events
30  shape:
31  - null
32  doc: Times of clustered events, in seconds. This may be a link to times field
33    in associated FeatureExtraction module.

3.10. Intracellular electrophysiology

This source module contains neurodata_types for intracellular electrophysiology data.

3.10.1. PatchClampSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.9.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: PatchClampSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: An abstract base class for patch-clamp data - stimulus or response, current
  4  or voltage.
  5attributes:
  6- name: stimulus_description
  7  dtype: text
  8  doc: Protocol/stimulus name for this patch-clamp dataset.
  9- name: sweep_number
 10  dtype: uint32
 11  doc: Sweep number, allows to group different PatchClampSeries together.
 12  required: false
 13- name: description
 14  dtype: text
 15  default_value: no description
 16  doc: Description of the time series.
 17  required: false
 18- name: comments
 19  dtype: text
 20  default_value: no comments
 21  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 22    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 23    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 24    computer-readable string.
 25  required: false
 26datasets:
 27- name: data
 28  dtype: numeric
 29  dims:
 30  - num_times
 31  shape:
 32  - null
 33  doc: Recorded voltage or current.
 34  attributes:
 35  - name: unit
 36    dtype: text
 37    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 38      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 39      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
 40  - name: conversion
 41    dtype: float32
 42    default_value: 1.0
 43    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 44      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 45      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 46      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 47      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 48      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 49      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 50      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 51      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 52    required: false
 53  - name: offset
 54    dtype: float32
 55    default_value: 0.0
 56    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 57      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 58      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 59      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 60      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 61    required: false
 62  - name: resolution
 63    dtype: float32
 64    default_value: -1.0
 65    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 66      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 67      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 68      -1.0.
 69    required: false
 70  - name: continuity
 71    dtype: text
 72    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 73      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 74      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 75      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 76      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 77      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 78      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 79      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 80      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 81    required: false
 82- name: gain
 83  dtype: float32
 84  doc: Gain of the recording, in units Volt/Amp (v-clamp) or Volt/Volt
 85    (c-clamp).
 86  quantity: '?'
 87- name: starting_time
 88  dtype: float64
 89  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 90    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 91    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 92  quantity: '?'
 93  attributes:
 94  - name: rate
 95    dtype: float32
 96    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 97  - name: unit
 98    dtype: text
 99    value: seconds
100    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
101- name: timestamps
102  dtype: float64
103  dims:
104  - num_times
105  shape:
106  - null
107  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
108    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
109  quantity: '?'
110  attributes:
111  - name: interval
112    dtype: int32
113    value: 1
114    doc: Value is '1'
115  - name: unit
116    dtype: text
117    value: seconds
118    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
119- name: control
120  dtype: uint8
121  dims:
122  - num_times
123  shape:
124  - null
125  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
126    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
127    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
128  quantity: '?'
129- name: control_description
130  dtype: text
131  dims:
132  - num_control_values
133  shape:
134  - null
135  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
136    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
137    == 0.
138  quantity: '?'
139groups:
140- name: sync
141  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
142    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
143    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
144    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
145    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
146    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
147  quantity: '?'
148links:
149- name: electrode
150  target_type: IntracellularElectrode
151  doc: Link to IntracellularElectrode object that describes the electrode that
152    was used to apply or record this data.

3.10.2. CurrentClampSeries

Extends: PatchClampSeries

Description: see Section 2.9.2

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: CurrentClampSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: PatchClampSeries
  3doc: Voltage data from an intracellular current-clamp recording. A corresponding
  4  CurrentClampStimulusSeries (stored separately as a stimulus) is used to store
  5  the current injected.
  6attributes:
  7- name: stimulus_description
  8  dtype: text
  9  doc: Protocol/stimulus name for this patch-clamp dataset.
 10- name: sweep_number
 11  dtype: uint32
 12  doc: Sweep number, allows to group different PatchClampSeries together.
 13  required: false
 14- name: description
 15  dtype: text
 16  default_value: no description
 17  doc: Description of the time series.
 18  required: false
 19- name: comments
 20  dtype: text
 21  default_value: no comments
 22  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 23    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 24    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 25    computer-readable string.
 26  required: false
 27datasets:
 28- name: data
 29  doc: Recorded voltage.
 30  attributes:
 31  - name: unit
 32    dtype: text
 33    value: volts
 34    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. which is fixed to
 35      'volts'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these units.
 36      To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add
 37      'offset'.
 38  - name: conversion
 39    dtype: float32
 40    default_value: 1.0
 41    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 42      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 43      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 44      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 45      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 46      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 47      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 48      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 49      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 50    required: false
 51  - name: offset
 52    dtype: float32
 53    default_value: 0.0
 54    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 55      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 56      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 57      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 58      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 59    required: false
 60  - name: resolution
 61    dtype: float32
 62    default_value: -1.0
 63    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 64      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 65      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 66      -1.0.
 67    required: false
 68  - name: continuity
 69    dtype: text
 70    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 71      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 72      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 73      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 74      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 75      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 76      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 77      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 78      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 79    required: false
 80- name: bias_current
 81  dtype: float32
 82  doc: Bias current, in amps.
 83  quantity: '?'
 84- name: bridge_balance
 85  dtype: float32
 86  doc: Bridge balance, in ohms.
 87  quantity: '?'
 88- name: capacitance_compensation
 89  dtype: float32
 90  doc: Capacitance compensation, in farads.
 91  quantity: '?'
 92- name: gain
 93  dtype: float32
 94  doc: Gain of the recording, in units Volt/Amp (v-clamp) or Volt/Volt
 95    (c-clamp).
 96  quantity: '?'
 97- name: starting_time
 98  dtype: float64
 99  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
100    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
101    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
102  quantity: '?'
103  attributes:
104  - name: rate
105    dtype: float32
106    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
107  - name: unit
108    dtype: text
109    value: seconds
110    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
111- name: timestamps
112  dtype: float64
113  dims:
114  - num_times
115  shape:
116  - null
117  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
118    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
119  quantity: '?'
120  attributes:
121  - name: interval
122    dtype: int32
123    value: 1
124    doc: Value is '1'
125  - name: unit
126    dtype: text
127    value: seconds
128    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
129- name: control
130  dtype: uint8
131  dims:
132  - num_times
133  shape:
134  - null
135  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
136    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
137    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
138  quantity: '?'
139- name: control_description
140  dtype: text
141  dims:
142  - num_control_values
143  shape:
144  - null
145  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
146    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
147    == 0.
148  quantity: '?'
149groups:
150- name: sync
151  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
152    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
153    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
154    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
155    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
156    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
157  quantity: '?'
158links:
159- name: electrode
160  target_type: IntracellularElectrode
161  doc: Link to IntracellularElectrode object that describes the electrode that
162    was used to apply or record this data.

3.10.3. IZeroClampSeries

Extends: CurrentClampSeries

Description: see Section 2.9.3

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: IZeroClampSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: CurrentClampSeries
  3doc: Voltage data from an intracellular recording when all current and amplifier
  4  settings are off (i.e., CurrentClampSeries fields will be zero). There is no
  5  CurrentClampStimulusSeries associated with an IZero series because the
  6  amplifier is disconnected and no stimulus can reach the cell.
  7attributes:
  8- name: stimulus_description
  9  dtype: text
 10  value: N/A
 11  doc: An IZeroClampSeries has no stimulus, so this attribute is automatically
 12    set to "N/A"
 13- name: sweep_number
 14  dtype: uint32
 15  doc: Sweep number, allows to group different PatchClampSeries together.
 16  required: false
 17- name: description
 18  dtype: text
 19  default_value: no description
 20  doc: Description of the time series.
 21  required: false
 22- name: comments
 23  dtype: text
 24  default_value: no comments
 25  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 26    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 27    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 28    computer-readable string.
 29  required: false
 30datasets:
 31- name: bias_current
 32  dtype: float32
 33  value: 0.0
 34  doc: Bias current, in amps, fixed to 0.0.
 35- name: bridge_balance
 36  dtype: float32
 37  value: 0.0
 38  doc: Bridge balance, in ohms, fixed to 0.0.
 39- name: capacitance_compensation
 40  dtype: float32
 41  value: 0.0
 42  doc: Capacitance compensation, in farads, fixed to 0.0.
 43- name: data
 44  doc: Recorded voltage.
 45  attributes:
 46  - name: unit
 47    dtype: text
 48    value: volts
 49    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. which is fixed to
 50      'volts'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these units.
 51      To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add
 52      'offset'.
 53  - name: conversion
 54    dtype: float32
 55    default_value: 1.0
 56    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 57      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 58      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 59      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 60      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 61      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 62      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 63      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 64      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 65    required: false
 66  - name: offset
 67    dtype: float32
 68    default_value: 0.0
 69    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 70      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 71      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 72      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 73      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 74    required: false
 75  - name: resolution
 76    dtype: float32
 77    default_value: -1.0
 78    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 79      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 80      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 81      -1.0.
 82    required: false
 83  - name: continuity
 84    dtype: text
 85    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 86      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 87      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 88      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 89      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 90      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 91      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 92      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 93      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 94    required: false
 95- name: gain
 96  dtype: float32
 97  doc: Gain of the recording, in units Volt/Amp (v-clamp) or Volt/Volt
 98    (c-clamp).
 99  quantity: '?'
100- name: starting_time
101  dtype: float64
102  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
103    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
104    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
105  quantity: '?'
106  attributes:
107  - name: rate
108    dtype: float32
109    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
110  - name: unit
111    dtype: text
112    value: seconds
113    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
114- name: timestamps
115  dtype: float64
116  dims:
117  - num_times
118  shape:
119  - null
120  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
121    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
122  quantity: '?'
123  attributes:
124  - name: interval
125    dtype: int32
126    value: 1
127    doc: Value is '1'
128  - name: unit
129    dtype: text
130    value: seconds
131    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
132- name: control
133  dtype: uint8
134  dims:
135  - num_times
136  shape:
137  - null
138  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
139    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
140    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
141  quantity: '?'
142- name: control_description
143  dtype: text
144  dims:
145  - num_control_values
146  shape:
147  - null
148  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
149    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
150    == 0.
151  quantity: '?'
152groups:
153- name: sync
154  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
155    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
156    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
157    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
158    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
159    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
160  quantity: '?'
161links:
162- name: electrode
163  target_type: IntracellularElectrode
164  doc: Link to IntracellularElectrode object that describes the electrode that
165    was used to apply or record this data.

3.10.4. CurrentClampStimulusSeries

Extends: PatchClampSeries

Description: see Section 2.9.4

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: CurrentClampStimulusSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: PatchClampSeries
  3doc: Stimulus current applied during current clamp recording.
  4attributes:
  5- name: stimulus_description
  6  dtype: text
  7  doc: Protocol/stimulus name for this patch-clamp dataset.
  8- name: sweep_number
  9  dtype: uint32
 10  doc: Sweep number, allows to group different PatchClampSeries together.
 11  required: false
 12- name: description
 13  dtype: text
 14  default_value: no description
 15  doc: Description of the time series.
 16  required: false
 17- name: comments
 18  dtype: text
 19  default_value: no comments
 20  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 21    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 22    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 23    computer-readable string.
 24  required: false
 25datasets:
 26- name: data
 27  doc: Stimulus current applied.
 28  attributes:
 29  - name: unit
 30    dtype: text
 31    value: amperes
 32    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. which is fixed to
 33      'amperes'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these units.
 34      To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add
 35      'offset'.
 36  - name: conversion
 37    dtype: float32
 38    default_value: 1.0
 39    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 40      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 41      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 42      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 43      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 44      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 45      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 46      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 47      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 48    required: false
 49  - name: offset
 50    dtype: float32
 51    default_value: 0.0
 52    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 53      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 54      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 55      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 56      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 57    required: false
 58  - name: resolution
 59    dtype: float32
 60    default_value: -1.0
 61    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 62      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 63      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 64      -1.0.
 65    required: false
 66  - name: continuity
 67    dtype: text
 68    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 69      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 70      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 71      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 72      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 73      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 74      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 75      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 76      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 77    required: false
 78- name: gain
 79  dtype: float32
 80  doc: Gain of the recording, in units Volt/Amp (v-clamp) or Volt/Volt
 81    (c-clamp).
 82  quantity: '?'
 83- name: starting_time
 84  dtype: float64
 85  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 86    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 87    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 88  quantity: '?'
 89  attributes:
 90  - name: rate
 91    dtype: float32
 92    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 93  - name: unit
 94    dtype: text
 95    value: seconds
 96    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 97- name: timestamps
 98  dtype: float64
 99  dims:
100  - num_times
101  shape:
102  - null
103  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
104    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
105  quantity: '?'
106  attributes:
107  - name: interval
108    dtype: int32
109    value: 1
110    doc: Value is '1'
111  - name: unit
112    dtype: text
113    value: seconds
114    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
115- name: control
116  dtype: uint8
117  dims:
118  - num_times
119  shape:
120  - null
121  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
122    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
123    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
124  quantity: '?'
125- name: control_description
126  dtype: text
127  dims:
128  - num_control_values
129  shape:
130  - null
131  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
132    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
133    == 0.
134  quantity: '?'
135groups:
136- name: sync
137  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
138    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
139    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
140    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
141    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
142    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
143  quantity: '?'
144links:
145- name: electrode
146  target_type: IntracellularElectrode
147  doc: Link to IntracellularElectrode object that describes the electrode that
148    was used to apply or record this data.

3.10.5. VoltageClampSeries

Extends: PatchClampSeries

Description: see Section 2.9.5

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: VoltageClampSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: PatchClampSeries
  3doc: Current data from an intracellular voltage-clamp recording. A corresponding
  4  VoltageClampStimulusSeries (stored separately as a stimulus) is used to store
  5  the voltage injected.
  6attributes:
  7- name: stimulus_description
  8  dtype: text
  9  doc: Protocol/stimulus name for this patch-clamp dataset.
 10- name: sweep_number
 11  dtype: uint32
 12  doc: Sweep number, allows to group different PatchClampSeries together.
 13  required: false
 14- name: description
 15  dtype: text
 16  default_value: no description
 17  doc: Description of the time series.
 18  required: false
 19- name: comments
 20  dtype: text
 21  default_value: no comments
 22  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 23    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 24    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 25    computer-readable string.
 26  required: false
 27datasets:
 28- name: data
 29  doc: Recorded current.
 30  attributes:
 31  - name: unit
 32    dtype: text
 33    value: amperes
 34    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. which is fixed to
 35      'amperes'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these units.
 36      To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add
 37      'offset'.
 38  - name: conversion
 39    dtype: float32
 40    default_value: 1.0
 41    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 42      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 43      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 44      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 45      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 46      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 47      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 48      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 49      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 50    required: false
 51  - name: offset
 52    dtype: float32
 53    default_value: 0.0
 54    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 55      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 56      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 57      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 58      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 59    required: false
 60  - name: resolution
 61    dtype: float32
 62    default_value: -1.0
 63    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 64      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 65      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 66      -1.0.
 67    required: false
 68  - name: continuity
 69    dtype: text
 70    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 71      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 72      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 73      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 74      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 75      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 76      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 77      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 78      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 79    required: false
 80- name: capacitance_fast
 81  dtype: float32
 82  doc: Fast capacitance, in farads.
 83  quantity: '?'
 84  attributes:
 85  - name: unit
 86    dtype: text
 87    value: farads
 88    doc: Unit of measurement for capacitance_fast, which is fixed to 'farads'.
 89- name: capacitance_slow
 90  dtype: float32
 91  doc: Slow capacitance, in farads.
 92  quantity: '?'
 93  attributes:
