 94  - name: unit
 95    dtype: text
 96    value: farads
 97    doc: Unit of measurement for capacitance_fast, which is fixed to 'farads'.
 98- name: resistance_comp_bandwidth
 99  dtype: float32
100  doc: Resistance compensation bandwidth, in hertz.
101  quantity: '?'
102  attributes:
103  - name: unit
104    dtype: text
105    value: hertz
106    doc: Unit of measurement for resistance_comp_bandwidth, which is fixed to
107      'hertz'.
108- name: resistance_comp_correction
109  dtype: float32
110  doc: Resistance compensation correction, in percent.
111  quantity: '?'
112  attributes:
113  - name: unit
114    dtype: text
115    value: percent
116    doc: Unit of measurement for resistance_comp_correction, which is fixed to
117      'percent'.
118- name: resistance_comp_prediction
119  dtype: float32
120  doc: Resistance compensation prediction, in percent.
121  quantity: '?'
122  attributes:
123  - name: unit
124    dtype: text
125    value: percent
126    doc: Unit of measurement for resistance_comp_prediction, which is fixed to
127      'percent'.
128- name: whole_cell_capacitance_comp
129  dtype: float32
130  doc: Whole cell capacitance compensation, in farads.
131  quantity: '?'
132  attributes:
133  - name: unit
134    dtype: text
135    value: farads
136    doc: Unit of measurement for whole_cell_capacitance_comp, which is fixed to
137      'farads'.
138- name: whole_cell_series_resistance_comp
139  dtype: float32
140  doc: Whole cell series resistance compensation, in ohms.
141  quantity: '?'
142  attributes:
143  - name: unit
144    dtype: text
145    value: ohms
146    doc: Unit of measurement for whole_cell_series_resistance_comp, which is
147      fixed to 'ohms'.
148- name: gain
149  dtype: float32
150  doc: Gain of the recording, in units Volt/Amp (v-clamp) or Volt/Volt
151    (c-clamp).
152  quantity: '?'
153- name: starting_time
154  dtype: float64
155  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
156    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
157    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
158  quantity: '?'
159  attributes:
160  - name: rate
161    dtype: float32
162    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
163  - name: unit
164    dtype: text
165    value: seconds
166    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
167- name: timestamps
168  dtype: float64
169  dims:
170  - num_times
171  shape:
172  - null
173  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
174    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
175  quantity: '?'
176  attributes:
177  - name: interval
178    dtype: int32
179    value: 1
180    doc: Value is '1'
181  - name: unit
182    dtype: text
183    value: seconds
184    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
185- name: control
186  dtype: uint8
187  dims:
188  - num_times
189  shape:
190  - null
191  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
192    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
193    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
194  quantity: '?'
195- name: control_description
196  dtype: text
197  dims:
198  - num_control_values
199  shape:
200  - null
201  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
202    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
203    == 0.
204  quantity: '?'
205groups:
206- name: sync
207  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
208    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
209    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
210    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
211    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
212    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
213  quantity: '?'
214links:
215- name: electrode
216  target_type: IntracellularElectrode
217  doc: Link to IntracellularElectrode object that describes the electrode that
218    was used to apply or record this data.

3.10.6. VoltageClampStimulusSeries

Extends: PatchClampSeries

Description: see Section 2.9.6

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: VoltageClampStimulusSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: PatchClampSeries
  3doc: Stimulus voltage applied during a voltage clamp recording.
  4attributes:
  5- name: stimulus_description
  6  dtype: text
  7  doc: Protocol/stimulus name for this patch-clamp dataset.
  8- name: sweep_number
  9  dtype: uint32
 10  doc: Sweep number, allows to group different PatchClampSeries together.
 11  required: false
 12- name: description
 13  dtype: text
 14  default_value: no description
 15  doc: Description of the time series.
 16  required: false
 17- name: comments
 18  dtype: text
 19  default_value: no comments
 20  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 21    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 22    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 23    computer-readable string.
 24  required: false
 25datasets:
 26- name: data
 27  doc: Stimulus voltage applied.
 28  attributes:
 29  - name: unit
 30    dtype: text
 31    value: volts
 32    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. which is fixed to
 33      'volts'. Actual stored values are not necessarily stored in these units.
 34      To access the data in these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add
 35      'offset'.
 36  - name: conversion
 37    dtype: float32
 38    default_value: 1.0
 39    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 40      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 41      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 42      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 43      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 44      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 45      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 46      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 47      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 48    required: false
 49  - name: offset
 50    dtype: float32
 51    default_value: 0.0
 52    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 53      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 54      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 55      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 56      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 57    required: false
 58  - name: resolution
 59    dtype: float32
 60    default_value: -1.0
 61    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 62      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 63      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 64      -1.0.
 65    required: false
 66  - name: continuity
 67    dtype: text
 68    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 69      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 70      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 71      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 72      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 73      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 74      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 75      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 76      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 77    required: false
 78- name: gain
 79  dtype: float32
 80  doc: Gain of the recording, in units Volt/Amp (v-clamp) or Volt/Volt
 81    (c-clamp).
 82  quantity: '?'
 83- name: starting_time
 84  dtype: float64
 85  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 86    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 87    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 88  quantity: '?'
 89  attributes:
 90  - name: rate
 91    dtype: float32
 92    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 93  - name: unit
 94    dtype: text
 95    value: seconds
 96    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 97- name: timestamps
 98  dtype: float64
 99  dims:
100  - num_times
101  shape:
102  - null
103  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
104    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
105  quantity: '?'
106  attributes:
107  - name: interval
108    dtype: int32
109    value: 1
110    doc: Value is '1'
111  - name: unit
112    dtype: text
113    value: seconds
114    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
115- name: control
116  dtype: uint8
117  dims:
118  - num_times
119  shape:
120  - null
121  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
122    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
123    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
124  quantity: '?'
125- name: control_description
126  dtype: text
127  dims:
128  - num_control_values
129  shape:
130  - null
131  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
132    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
133    == 0.
134  quantity: '?'
135groups:
136- name: sync
137  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
138    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
139    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
140    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
141    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
142    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
143  quantity: '?'
144links:
145- name: electrode
146  target_type: IntracellularElectrode
147  doc: Link to IntracellularElectrode object that describes the electrode that
148    was used to apply or record this data.

3.10.7. IntracellularElectrode

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.9.7

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: IntracellularElectrode
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 3doc: An intracellular electrode and its metadata.
 4datasets:
 5- name: cell_id
 6  dtype: text
 7  doc: unique ID of the cell
 8  quantity: '?'
 9- name: description
10  dtype: text
11  doc: Description of electrode (e.g.,  whole-cell, sharp, etc.).
12- name: filtering
13  dtype: text
14  doc: Electrode specific filtering.
15  quantity: '?'
16- name: initial_access_resistance
17  dtype: text
18  doc: Initial access resistance.
19  quantity: '?'
20- name: location
21  dtype: text
22  doc: Location of the electrode. Specify the area, layer, comments on
23    estimation of area/layer, stereotaxic coordinates if in vivo, etc. Use
24    standard atlas names for anatomical regions when possible.
25  quantity: '?'
26- name: resistance
27  dtype: text
28  doc: Electrode resistance, in ohms.
29  quantity: '?'
30- name: seal
31  dtype: text
32  doc: Information about seal used for recording.
33  quantity: '?'
34- name: slice
35  dtype: text
36  doc: Information about slice used for recording.
37  quantity: '?'
38links:
39- name: device
40  target_type: Device
41  doc: Device that was used to record from this electrode.

3.10.8. SweepTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.9.8

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: SweepTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3doc: '[DEPRECATED] Table used to group different PatchClampSeries. SweepTable is being
 4  replaced by IntracellularRecordingsTable and SimultaneousRecordingsTable tables.
 5  Additional SequentialRecordingsTable, RepetitionsTable, and ExperimentalConditions
 6  tables provide enhanced support for experiment metadata.'
 7attributes:
 8- name: colnames
 9  dtype: text
10  dims:
11  - num_columns
12  shape:
13  - null
14  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
15    order to the columns.
16- name: description
17  dtype: text
18  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
19datasets:
20- name: sweep_number
21  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
22  dtype: uint32
23  doc: Sweep number of the PatchClampSeries in that row.
24- name: series
25  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
26  dtype:
27    target_type: PatchClampSeries
28    reftype: object
29  doc: The PatchClampSeries with the sweep number in that row.
30- name: series_index
31  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
32  doc: Index for series.
33- name: id
34  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
35  dtype: int
36  dims:
37  - num_rows
38  shape:
39  - null
40  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
41- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
42  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
43  quantity: '*'

 7  value: Table for storing intracellular electrode related metadata.

16    order to the columns.

3.10.12. IntracellularRecordingsTable

Extends: AlignedDynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.9.12

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: IntracellularRecordingsTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: AlignedDynamicTable
 3name: intracellular_recordings
 4doc: A table to group together a stimulus and response from a single electrode
 5  and a single simultaneous recording. Each row in the table represents a single
 6  recording consisting typically of a stimulus and a corresponding response. In
 7  some cases, however, only a stimulus or a response is recorded as part of an
 8  experiment. In this case, both the stimulus and response will point to the
 9  same TimeSeries while the idx_start and count of the invalid column will be
10  set to -1, thus, indicating that no values have been recorded for the stimulus
11  or response, respectively. Note, a recording MUST contain at least a stimulus
12  or a response. Typically the stimulus and response are PatchClampSeries.
13  However, the use of AD/DA channels that are not associated to an electrode is
14  also common in intracellular electrophysiology, in which case other TimeSeries
15  may be used.
16attributes:
17- name: description
18  dtype: text
19  value: A table to group together a stimulus and response from a single
20    electrode and a single simultaneous recording and for storing metadata about
21    the intracellular recording.
22  doc: Description of the contents of this table. Inherited from
23    AlignedDynamicTable and overwritten here to fix the value of the attribute.
24- name: categories
25  dtype: text
26  dims:
27  - num_categories
28  shape:
29  - null
30  doc: The names of the categories in this AlignedDynamicTable. Each category is
31    represented by one DynamicTable stored in the parent group. This attribute
32    should be used to specify an order of categories and the category names must
33    match the names of the corresponding DynamicTable in the group.
34- name: colnames
35  dtype: text
36  dims:
37  - num_columns
38  shape:
39  - null
40  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
41    order to the columns.
42datasets:
43- name: id
44  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
45  dtype: int
46  dims:
47  - num_rows
48  shape:
49  - null
50  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
51- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
52  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
53  quantity: '*'
54groups:
55- name: electrodes
56  neurodata_type_inc: IntracellularElectrodesTable
57  doc: Table for storing intracellular electrode related metadata.
58- name: stimuli
59  neurodata_type_inc: IntracellularStimuliTable
60  doc: Table for storing intracellular stimulus related metadata.
61- name: responses
62  neurodata_type_inc: IntracellularResponsesTable
63  doc: Table for storing intracellular response related metadata.
64- neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
65  doc: A DynamicTable representing a particular category for columns in the
66    AlignedDynamicTable parent container. The table MUST be aligned with (i.e.,
67    have the same number of rows) as all other DynamicTables stored in the
68    AlignedDynamicTable parent container. The name of the category is given by
69    the name of the DynamicTable and its description by the description
70    attribute of the DynamicTable.
71  quantity: '*'

3.10.13. SimultaneousRecordingsTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.9.13

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: SimultaneousRecordingsTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3name: simultaneous_recordings
 4doc: A table for grouping different intracellular recordings from the
 5  IntracellularRecordingsTable table together that were recorded simultaneously
 6  from different electrodes.
 7attributes:
 8- name: colnames
 9  dtype: text
10  dims:
11  - num_columns
12  shape:
13  - null
14  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
15    order to the columns.
16- name: description
17  dtype: text
18  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
19datasets:
20- name: recordings
21  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
22  doc: A reference to one or more rows in the IntracellularRecordingsTable
23    table.
24  attributes:
25  - name: table
26    dtype:
27      target_type: IntracellularRecordingsTable
28      reftype: object
29    doc: Reference to the IntracellularRecordingsTable table that this table
30      region applies to. This specializes the attribute inherited from
31      DynamicTableRegion to fix the type of table that can be referenced here.
32- name: recordings_index
33  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
34  doc: Index dataset for the recordings column.
35- name: id
36  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
37  dtype: int
38  dims:
39  - num_rows
40  shape:
41  - null
42  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
43- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
44  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
45  quantity: '*'

3.10.14. SequentialRecordingsTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.9.14

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: SequentialRecordingsTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3name: sequential_recordings
 4doc: A table for grouping different sequential recordings from the
 5  SimultaneousRecordingsTable table together. This is typically used to group
 6  together sequential recordings where a sequence of stimuli of the same type
 7  with varying parameters have been presented in a sequence.
 8attributes:
 9- name: colnames
10  dtype: text
11  dims:
12  - num_columns
13  shape:
14  - null
15  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
16    order to the columns.
17- name: description
18  dtype: text
19  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
20datasets:
21- name: simultaneous_recordings
22  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
23  doc: A reference to one or more rows in the SimultaneousRecordingsTable table.
24  attributes:
25  - name: table
26    dtype:
27      target_type: SimultaneousRecordingsTable
28      reftype: object
29    doc: Reference to the SimultaneousRecordingsTable table that this table
30      region applies to. This specializes the attribute inherited from
31      DynamicTableRegion to fix the type of table that can be referenced here.
32- name: simultaneous_recordings_index
33  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
34  doc: Index dataset for the simultaneous_recordings column.
35- name: stimulus_type
36  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
37  dtype: text
38  doc: The type of stimulus used for the sequential recording.
39- name: id
40  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
41  dtype: int
42  dims:
43  - num_rows
44  shape:
45  - null
46  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
47- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
48  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
49  quantity: '*'

3.10.15. RepetitionsTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.9.15

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: RepetitionsTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3name: repetitions
 4doc: A table for grouping different sequential intracellular recordings
 5  together. With each SequentialRecording typically representing a particular
 6  type of stimulus, the RepetitionsTable table is typically used to group sets
 7  of stimuli applied in sequence.
 8attributes:
 9- name: colnames
10  dtype: text
11  dims:
12  - num_columns
13  shape:
14  - null
15  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
16    order to the columns.
17- name: description
18  dtype: text
19  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
20datasets:
21- name: sequential_recordings
22  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
23  doc: A reference to one or more rows in the SequentialRecordingsTable table.
24  attributes:
25  - name: table
26    dtype:
27      target_type: SequentialRecordingsTable
28      reftype: object
29    doc: Reference to the SequentialRecordingsTable table that this table region
30      applies to. This specializes the attribute inherited from
31      DynamicTableRegion to fix the type of table that can be referenced here.
32- name: sequential_recordings_index
33  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
34  doc: Index dataset for the sequential_recordings column.
35- name: id
36  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
37  dtype: int
38  dims:
39  - num_rows
40  shape:
41  - null
42  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
43- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
44  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
45  quantity: '*'

3.10.16. ExperimentalConditionsTable

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.9.16

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: ExperimentalConditionsTable
 2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
 3name: experimental_conditions
 4doc: A table for grouping different intracellular recording repetitions together
 5  that belong to the same experimental condition.
 6attributes:
 7- name: colnames
 8  dtype: text
 9  dims:
10  - num_columns
11  shape:
12  - null
13  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
14    order to the columns.
15- name: description
16  dtype: text
17  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
18datasets:
19- name: repetitions
20  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
21  doc: A reference to one or more rows in the RepetitionsTable table.
22  attributes:
23  - name: table
24    dtype:
25      target_type: RepetitionsTable
26      reftype: object
27    doc: Reference to the RepetitionsTable table that this table region applies
28      to. This specializes the attribute inherited from DynamicTableRegion to
29      fix the type of table that can be referenced here.
30- name: repetitions_index
31  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
32  doc: Index dataset for the repetitions column.
33- name: id
34  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
35  dtype: int
36  dims:
37  - num_rows
38  shape:
39  - null
40  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
41- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
42  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
43  quantity: '*'

3.11. Optogenetics

This source module contains neurodata_types for opto-genetics data.

3.11.1. OptogeneticSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.10.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: OptogeneticSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: An optogenetic stimulus.
  4attributes:
  5- name: description
  6  dtype: text
  7  default_value: no description
  8  doc: Description of the time series.
  9  required: false
 10- name: comments
 11  dtype: text
 12  default_value: no comments
 13  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 14    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 15    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 16    computer-readable string.
 17  required: false
 18datasets:
 19- name: data
 20  dtype: numeric
 21  dims:
 22  - - num_times
 23  - - num_times
 24    - num_rois
 25  shape:
 26  - - null
 27  - - null
 28    - null
 29  doc: Applied power for optogenetic stimulus, in watts. Shape can be 1D or 2D.
 30    2D data is meant to be used in an extension of OptogeneticSeries that
 31    defines what the second dimension represents.
 32  attributes:
 33  - name: unit
 34    dtype: text
 35    value: watts
 36    doc: Unit of measurement for data, which is fixed to 'watts'.
 37  - name: conversion
 38    dtype: float32
 39    default_value: 1.0
 40    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 41      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 42      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 43      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 44      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 45      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 46      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 47      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 48      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 49    required: false
 50  - name: offset
 51    dtype: float32
 52    default_value: 0.0
 53    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 54      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 55      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 56      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 57      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 58    required: false
 59  - name: resolution
 60    dtype: float32
 61    default_value: -1.0
 62    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 63      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 64      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 65      -1.0.
 66    required: false
 67  - name: continuity
 68    dtype: text
 69    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 70      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 71      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 72      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 73      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 74      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 75      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 76      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 77      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 78    required: false
 79- name: starting_time
 80  dtype: float64
 81  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 82    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 83    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 84  quantity: '?'
 85  attributes:
 86  - name: rate
 87    dtype: float32
 88    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 89  - name: unit
 90    dtype: text
 91    value: seconds
 92    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 93- name: timestamps
 94  dtype: float64
 95  dims:
 96  - num_times
 97  shape:
 98  - null
 99  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
100    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
101  quantity: '?'
102  attributes:
103  - name: interval
104    dtype: int32
105    value: 1
106    doc: Value is '1'
107  - name: unit
108    dtype: text
109    value: seconds
110    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
111- name: control
112  dtype: uint8
113  dims:
114  - num_times
115  shape:
116  - null
117  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
118    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
119    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
120  quantity: '?'
121- name: control_description
122  dtype: text
123  dims:
124  - num_control_values
125  shape:
126  - null
127  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
128    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
129    == 0.
130  quantity: '?'
131groups:
132- name: sync
133  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
134    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
135    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
136    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
137    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
138    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
139  quantity: '?'
140links:
141- name: site
142  target_type: OptogeneticStimulusSite
143  doc: Link to OptogeneticStimulusSite object that describes the site to which
144    this stimulus was applied.

3.11.2. OptogeneticStimulusSite

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.10.2

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: OptogeneticStimulusSite
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 3doc: A site of optogenetic stimulation.
 4datasets:
 5- name: description
 6  dtype: text
 7  doc: Description of stimulation site.
 8- name: excitation_lambda
 9  dtype: float32
10  doc: Excitation wavelength, in nm.
11- name: location
12  dtype: text
13  doc: Location of the stimulation site. Specify the area, layer, comments on
14    estimation of area/layer, stereotaxic coordinates if in vivo, etc. Use
15    standard atlas names for anatomical regions when possible.
16links:
17- name: device
18  target_type: Device
19  doc: Device that generated the stimulus.

3.12. Optical physiology

This source module contains neurodata_types for optical physiology data.

3.12.1. OnePhotonSeries

Extends: ImageSeries

Description: see Section 2.11.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: OnePhotonSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: ImageSeries
  3doc: Image stack recorded over time from 1-photon microscope.
  4attributes:
  5- name: pmt_gain
  6  dtype: float32
  7  doc: Photomultiplier gain.
  8  required: false
  9- name: scan_line_rate
 10  dtype: float32
 11  doc: Lines imaged per second. This is also stored in /general/optophysiology
 12    but is kept here as it is useful information for analysis, and so good to be
 13    stored w/ the actual data.
 14  required: false
 15- name: exposure_time
 16  dtype: float32
 17  doc: Exposure time of the sample; often the inverse of the frequency.
 18  required: false
 19- name: binning
 20  dtype: uint8
 21  doc: Amount of pixels combined into 'bins'; could be 1, 2, 4, 8, etc.
 22  required: false
 23- name: power
 24  dtype: float32
 25  doc: Power of the excitation in mW, if known.
 26  required: false
 27- name: intensity
 28  dtype: float32
 29  doc: Intensity of the excitation in mW/mm^2, if known.
 30  required: false
 31- name: description
 32  dtype: text
 33  default_value: no description
 34  doc: Description of the time series.
 35  required: false
 36- name: comments
 37  dtype: text
 38  default_value: no comments
 39  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 40    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 41    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 42    computer-readable string.
 43  required: false
 44datasets:
 45- name: data
 46  dtype: numeric
 47  dims:
 48  - - frame
 49    - x
 50    - y
 51  - - frame
 52    - x
 53    - y
 54    - z
 55  shape:
 56  - - null
 57    - null
 58    - null
 59  - - null
 60    - null
 61    - null
 62    - null
 63  doc: Binary data representing images across frames. If data are stored in an
 64    external file, this should be an empty 3D array.
 65  attributes:
 66  - name: conversion
 67    dtype: float32
 68    default_value: 1.0
 69    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 70      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 71      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 72      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 73      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 74      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 75      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 76      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 77      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 78    required: false
 79  - name: offset
 80    dtype: float32
 81    default_value: 0.0
 82    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 83      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 84      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 85      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 86      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 87    required: false
 88  - name: resolution
 89    dtype: float32
 90    default_value: -1.0
 91    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 92      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 93      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 94      -1.0.
 95    required: false
 96  - name: unit
 97    dtype: text
 98    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 99      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
100      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
101  - name: continuity
102    dtype: text
103    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
104      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
105      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
106      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
107      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
108      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
109      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
110      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
111      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
112    required: false
113- name: dimension
114  dtype: int32
115  dims:
116  - rank
117  shape:
118  - null
119  doc: Number of pixels on x, y, (and z) axes.
120  quantity: '?'
121- name: external_file
122  dtype: text
123  dims:
124  - num_files
125  shape:
126  - null
127  doc: Paths to one or more external file(s). The field is only present if
128    format='external'. This is only relevant if the image series is stored in
129    the file system as one or more image file(s). This field should NOT be used
130    if the image is stored in another NWB file and that file is linked to this
131    file.
132  quantity: '?'
133  attributes:
134  - name: starting_frame
135    dtype: int32
136    dims:
137    - num_files
138    shape:
139    - null
140    doc: Each external image may contain one or more consecutive frames of the
141      full ImageSeries. This attribute serves as an index to indicate which
142      frames each file contains, to facilitate random access. The
143      'starting_frame' attribute, hence, contains a list of frame numbers within
144      the full ImageSeries of the first frame of each file listed in the parent
145      'external_file' dataset. Zero-based indexing is used (hence, the first
146      element will always be zero). For example, if the 'external_file' dataset
147      has three paths to files and the first file has 5 frames, the second file
148      has 10 frames, and the third file has 20 frames, then this attribute will
149      have values [0, 5, 15]. If there is a single external file that holds all
150      of the frames of the ImageSeries (and so there is a single element in the
151      'external_file' dataset), then this attribute should have value [0].
152- name: format
153  dtype: text
154  default_value: raw
155  doc: Format of image. If this is 'external', then the attribute
156    'external_file' contains the path information to the image files. If this is
157    'raw', then the raw (single-channel) binary data is stored in the 'data'
158    dataset. If this attribute is not present, then the default format='raw'
159    case is assumed.
160  quantity: '?'
161- name: starting_time
162  dtype: float64
163  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
164    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
165    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
166  quantity: '?'
167  attributes:
168  - name: rate
169    dtype: float32
170    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
171  - name: unit
172    dtype: text
173    value: seconds
174    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
175- name: timestamps
176  dtype: float64
177  dims:
178  - num_times
179  shape:
180  - null
181  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
182    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
183  quantity: '?'
184  attributes:
185  - name: interval
186    dtype: int32
187    value: 1
188    doc: Value is '1'
189  - name: unit
190    dtype: text
191    value: seconds
192    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
193- name: control
194  dtype: uint8
195  dims:
196  - num_times
197  shape:
198  - null
199  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
200    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
201    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
202  quantity: '?'
203- name: control_description
204  dtype: text
205  dims:
206  - num_control_values
207  shape:
208  - null
209  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
210    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
211    == 0.
212  quantity: '?'
213groups:
214- name: sync
215  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
216    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
217    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
218    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
219    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
220    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
221  quantity: '?'
222links:
223- name: imaging_plane
224  target_type: ImagingPlane
225  doc: Link to ImagingPlane object from which this TimeSeries data was
226    generated.
227- name: device
228  target_type: Device
229  doc: Link to the Device object that was used to capture these images.
230  quantity: '?'

3.12.2. TwoPhotonSeries

Extends: ImageSeries

Description: see Section 2.11.2

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: TwoPhotonSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: ImageSeries
  3doc: Image stack recorded over time from 2-photon microscope.
  4attributes:
  5- name: pmt_gain
  6  dtype: float32
  7  doc: Photomultiplier gain.
  8  required: false
  9- name: scan_line_rate
 10  dtype: float32
 11  doc: Lines imaged per second. This is also stored in /general/optophysiology
 12    but is kept here as it is useful information for analysis, and so good to be
 13    stored w/ the actual data.
 14  required: false
 15- name: description
 16  dtype: text
 17  default_value: no description
 18  doc: Description of the time series.
 19  required: false
 20- name: comments
 21  dtype: text
 22  default_value: no comments
 23  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 24    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 25    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 26    computer-readable string.
 27  required: false
 28datasets:
 29- name: field_of_view
 30  dtype: float32
 31  dims:
 32  - - width|height
 33  - - width|height|depth
 34  shape:
 35  - - 2
 36  - - 3
 37  doc: Width, height and depth of image, or imaged area, in meters.
 38  quantity: '?'
 39- name: data
 40  dtype: numeric
 41  dims:
 42  - - frame
 43    - x
 44    - y
 45  - - frame
 46    - x
 47    - y
 48    - z
 49  shape:
 50  - - null
 51    - null
 52    - null
 53  - - null
 54    - null
 55    - null
 56    - null
 57  doc: Binary data representing images across frames. If data are stored in an
 58    external file, this should be an empty 3D array.
 59  attributes:
 60  - name: conversion
 61    dtype: float32
 62    default_value: 1.0
 63    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 64      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 65      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 66      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 67      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 68      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 69      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 70      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 71      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 72    required: false
 73  - name: offset
 74    dtype: float32
 75    default_value: 0.0
 76    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 77      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 78      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 79      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 80      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 81    required: false
 82  - name: resolution
 83    dtype: float32
 84    default_value: -1.0
 85    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 86      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 87      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 88      -1.0.
 89    required: false
 90  - name: unit
 91    dtype: text
 92    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 93      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 94      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
 95  - name: continuity
 96    dtype: text
 97    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 98      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 99      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
100      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
101      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
102      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
103      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
104      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
105      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
106    required: false
107- name: dimension
108  dtype: int32
109  dims:
110  - rank
111  shape:
112  - null
113  doc: Number of pixels on x, y, (and z) axes.
114  quantity: '?'
115- name: external_file
116  dtype: text
117  dims:
118  - num_files
119  shape:
120  - null
121  doc: Paths to one or more external file(s). The field is only present if
122    format='external'. This is only relevant if the image series is stored in
123    the file system as one or more image file(s). This field should NOT be used
124    if the image is stored in another NWB file and that file is linked to this
125    file.
126  quantity: '?'
127  attributes:
128  - name: starting_frame
129    dtype: int32
130    dims:
131    - num_files
132    shape:
133    - null
134    doc: Each external image may contain one or more consecutive frames of the
135      full ImageSeries. This attribute serves as an index to indicate which
136      frames each file contains, to facilitate random access. The
137      'starting_frame' attribute, hence, contains a list of frame numbers within
138      the full ImageSeries of the first frame of each file listed in the parent
139      'external_file' dataset. Zero-based indexing is used (hence, the first
140      element will always be zero). For example, if the 'external_file' dataset
141      has three paths to files and the first file has 5 frames, the second file
142      has 10 frames, and the third file has 20 frames, then this attribute will
143      have values [0, 5, 15]. If there is a single external file that holds all
144      of the frames of the ImageSeries (and so there is a single element in the
145      'external_file' dataset), then this attribute should have value [0].
146- name: format
147  dtype: text
148  default_value: raw
149  doc: Format of image. If this is 'external', then the attribute
150    'external_file' contains the path information to the image files. If this is
151    'raw', then the raw (single-channel) binary data is stored in the 'data'
152    dataset. If this attribute is not present, then the default format='raw'
153    case is assumed.
154  quantity: '?'
155- name: starting_time
156  dtype: float64
157  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
158    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
159    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
160  quantity: '?'
161  attributes:
162  - name: rate
163    dtype: float32
164    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
165  - name: unit
166    dtype: text
167    value: seconds
168    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
169- name: timestamps
170  dtype: float64
171  dims:
172  - num_times
173  shape:
174  - null
175  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
176    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
177  quantity: '?'
178  attributes:
179  - name: interval
180    dtype: int32
181    value: 1
182    doc: Value is '1'
183  - name: unit
184    dtype: text
185    value: seconds
186    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
187- name: control
188  dtype: uint8
189  dims:
190  - num_times
191  shape:
192  - null
193  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
194    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
195    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
196  quantity: '?'
197- name: control_description
198  dtype: text
199  dims:
200  - num_control_values
201  shape:
202  - null
203  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
204    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
205    == 0.
206  quantity: '?'
207groups:
208- name: sync
209  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
210    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
211    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
212    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
213    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
214    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
215  quantity: '?'
216links:
217- name: imaging_plane
218  target_type: ImagingPlane
219  doc: Link to ImagingPlane object from which this TimeSeries data was
220    generated.
221- name: device
222  target_type: Device
223  doc: Link to the Device object that was used to capture these images.
224  quantity: '?'

3.12.3. RoiResponseSeries

Extends: TimeSeries

Description: see Section 2.11.3

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: RoiResponseSeries
  2neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
  3doc: ROI responses over an imaging plane. The first dimension represents time.
  4  The second dimension, if present, represents ROIs.
  5attributes:
  6- name: description
  7  dtype: text
  8  default_value: no description
  9  doc: Description of the time series.
 10  required: false
 11- name: comments
 12  dtype: text
 13  default_value: no comments
 14  doc: Human-readable comments about the TimeSeries. This second descriptive
 15    field can be used to store additional information, or descriptive
 16    information if the primary description field is populated with a
 17    computer-readable string.
 18  required: false
 19datasets:
 20- name: data
 21  dtype: numeric
 22  dims:
 23  - - num_times
 24  - - num_times
 25    - num_ROIs
 26  shape:
 27  - - null
 28  - - null
 29    - null
 30  doc: Signals from ROIs.
 31  attributes:
 32  - name: conversion
 33    dtype: float32
 34    default_value: 1.0
 35    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 36      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 37      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 38      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 39      acquisition system stores values in this object as signed 16-bit integers
 40      (int16 range -32,768 to 32,767) that correspond to a 5V range (-2.5V to
 41      2.5V), and the data acquisition system gain is 8000X, then the
 42      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition values to
 43      recorded volts is 2.5/32768/8000 = 9.5367e-9.
 44    required: false
 45  - name: offset
 46    dtype: float32
 47    default_value: 0.0
 48    doc: Scalar to add to the data after scaling by 'conversion' to finalize its
 49      coercion to the specified 'unit'. Two common examples of this include (a)
 50      data stored in an unsigned type that requires a shift after scaling to
 51      re-center the data, and (b) specialized recording devices that naturally
 52      cause a scalar offset with respect to the true units.
 53    required: false
 54  - name: resolution
 55    dtype: float32
 56    default_value: -1.0
 57    doc: Smallest meaningful difference between values in data, stored in the
 58      specified by unit, e.g., the change in value of the least significant bit,
 59      or a larger number if signal noise is known to be present. If unknown, use
 60      -1.0.
 61    required: false
 62  - name: unit
 63    dtype: text
 64    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. Actual stored
 65      values are not necessarily stored in these units. To access the data in
 66      these units, multiply 'data' by 'conversion' and add 'offset'.
 67  - name: continuity
 68    dtype: text
 69    doc: Optionally describe the continuity of the data. Can be "continuous",
 70      "instantaneous", or "step". For example, a voltage trace would be
 71      "continuous", because samples are recorded from a continuous process. An
 72      array of lick times would be "instantaneous", because the data represents
 73      distinct moments in time. Times of image presentations would be "step"
 74      because the picture remains the same until the next timepoint. This field
 75      is optional, but is useful in providing information about the underlying
 76      data. It may inform the way this data is interpreted, the way it is
 77      visualized, and what analysis methods are applicable.
 78    required: false
 79- name: rois
 80  neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTableRegion
 81  doc: DynamicTableRegion referencing into an ROITable containing information on
 82    the ROIs stored in this timeseries.
 83- name: starting_time
 84  dtype: float64
 85  doc: Timestamp of the first sample in seconds. When timestamps are uniformly
 86    spaced, the timestamp of the first sample can be specified and all
 87    subsequent ones calculated from the sampling rate attribute.
 88  quantity: '?'
 89  attributes:
 90  - name: rate
 91    dtype: float32
 92    doc: Sampling rate, in Hz.
 93  - name: unit
 94    dtype: text
 95    value: seconds
 96    doc: Unit of measurement for time, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
 97- name: timestamps
 98  dtype: float64
 99  dims:
100  - num_times
101  shape:
102  - null
103  doc: Timestamps for samples stored in data, in seconds, relative to the common
104    experiment master-clock stored in NWBFile.timestamps_reference_time.
105  quantity: '?'
106  attributes:
107  - name: interval
108    dtype: int32
109    value: 1
110    doc: Value is '1'
111  - name: unit
112    dtype: text
113    value: seconds
114    doc: Unit of measurement for timestamps, which is fixed to 'seconds'.
115- name: control
116  dtype: uint8
117  dims:
118  - num_times
119  shape:
120  - null
121  doc: Numerical labels that apply to each time point in data for the purpose of
122    querying and slicing data by these values. If present, the length of this
123    array should be the same size as the first dimension of data.
124  quantity: '?'
125- name: control_description
126  dtype: text
127  dims:
128  - num_control_values
129  shape:
130  - null
131  doc: Description of each control value. Must be present if control is present.
132    If present, control_description[0] should describe time points where control
133    == 0.
134  quantity: '?'
135groups:
136- name: sync
137  doc: Lab-specific time and sync information as provided directly from hardware
138    devices and that is necessary for aligning all acquired time information to
139    a common timebase. The timestamp array stores time in the common timebase.
140    This group will usually only be populated in TimeSeries that are stored
141    external to the NWB file, in files storing raw data. Once timestamp data is
142    calculated, the contents of 'sync' are mostly for archival purposes.
143  quantity: '?'

3.12.4. DfOverF

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.11.4

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: DfOverF
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: DfOverF
 4doc: dF/F information about a region of interest (ROI). Storage hierarchy of
 5  dF/F should be the same as for segmentation (i.e., same names for ROIs and for
 6  image planes).
 7groups:
 8- neurodata_type_inc: RoiResponseSeries
 9  doc: RoiResponseSeries object(s) containing dF/F for a ROI.
10  quantity: +

3.12.5. Fluorescence

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.11.5

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: Fluorescence
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: Fluorescence
 4doc: Fluorescence information about a region of interest (ROI). Storage
 5  hierarchy of fluorescence should be the same as for segmentation (ie, same
 6  names for ROIs and for image planes).
 7groups:
 8- neurodata_type_inc: RoiResponseSeries
 9  doc: RoiResponseSeries object(s) containing fluorescence data for a ROI.
10  quantity: +

3.12.6. ImageSegmentation

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.11.6

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: ImageSegmentation
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: ImageSegmentation
 4doc: Stores pixels in an image that represent different regions of interest
 5  (ROIs) or masks. All segmentation for a given imaging plane is stored
 6  together, with storage for multiple imaging planes (masks) supported. Each ROI
 7  is stored in its own subgroup, with the ROI group containing both a 2D mask
 8  and a list of pixels that make up this mask. Segments can also be used for
 9  masking neuropil. If segmentation is allowed to change with time, a new
10  imaging plane (or module) is required and ROI names should remain consistent
11  between them.
12groups:
13- neurodata_type_inc: PlaneSegmentation
14  doc: Results from image segmentation of a specific imaging plane.
15  quantity: +

3.12.7. PlaneSegmentation

Extends: DynamicTable

Description: see Section 2.11.7

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: PlaneSegmentation
  2neurodata_type_inc: DynamicTable
  3doc: Results from image segmentation of a specific imaging plane. At least one
  4  of `image_mask`, `pixel_mask`, or `voxel_mask` is required.
  5attributes:
  6- name: colnames
  7  dtype: text
  8  dims:
  9  - num_columns
 10  shape:
 11  - null
 12  doc: The names of the columns in this table. This should be used to specify an
 13    order to the columns.
 14- name: description
 15  dtype: text
 16  doc: Description of what is in this dynamic table.
 17datasets:
 18- name: image_mask
 19  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 20  dims:
 21  - - num_roi
 22    - num_x
 23    - num_y
 24  - - num_roi
 25    - num_x
 26    - num_y
 27    - num_z
 28  shape:
 29  - - null
 30    - null
 31    - null
 32  - - null
 33    - null
 34    - null
 35    - null
 36  doc: ROI masks for each ROI. Each image mask is the size of the original
 37    imaging plane (or volume) and members of the ROI are finite non-zero. At
 38    least one of `image_mask`, `pixel_mask`, or `voxel_mask` is required.
 39  quantity: '?'
 40- name: pixel_mask_index
 41  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
 42  doc: Index into pixel_mask.
 43  quantity: '?'
 44- name: pixel_mask
 45  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 46  dtype:
 47  - name: x
 48    dtype: uint32
 49    doc: Pixel x-coordinate.
 50  - name: y
 51    dtype: uint32
 52    doc: Pixel y-coordinate.
 53  - name: weight
 54    dtype: float32
 55    doc: Weight of the pixel.
 56  doc: 'Pixel masks for each ROI: a list of indices and weights for the ROI. Pixel
 57    masks are concatenated and parsing of this dataset is maintained by the PlaneSegmentation.
 58    At least one of `image_mask`, `pixel_mask`, or `voxel_mask` is required.'
 59  quantity: '?'
 60- name: voxel_mask_index
 61  neurodata_type_inc: VectorIndex
 62  doc: Index into voxel_mask.
 63  quantity: '?'
 64- name: voxel_mask
 65  neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 66  dtype:
 67  - name: x
 68    dtype: uint32
 69    doc: Voxel x-coordinate.
 70  - name: y
 71    dtype: uint32
 72    doc: Voxel y-coordinate.
 73  - name: z
 74    dtype: uint32
 75    doc: Voxel z-coordinate.
 76  - name: weight
 77    dtype: float32
 78    doc: Weight of the voxel.
 79  doc: 'Voxel masks for each ROI: a list of indices and weights for the ROI. Voxel
 80    masks are concatenated and parsing of this dataset is maintained by the PlaneSegmentation.
 81    At least one of `image_mask`, `pixel_mask`, or `voxel_mask` is required.'
 82  quantity: '?'
 83- name: id
 84  neurodata_type_inc: ElementIdentifiers
 85  dtype: int
 86  dims:
 87  - num_rows
 88  shape:
 89  - null
 90  doc: Array of unique identifiers for the rows of this dynamic table.
 91- neurodata_type_inc: VectorData
 92  doc: Vector columns, including index columns, of this dynamic table.
 93  quantity: '*'
 94groups:
 95- name: reference_images
 96  doc: Image stacks that the segmentation masks apply to.
 97  groups:
 98  - neurodata_type_inc: ImageSeries
 99    doc: One or more image stacks that the masks apply to (can be one-element
100      stack).
101    quantity: '*'
102links:
103- name: imaging_plane
104  target_type: ImagingPlane
105  doc: Link to ImagingPlane object from which this data was generated.

3.12.8. ImagingPlane

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.11.8

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: ImagingPlane
  2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
  3doc: An imaging plane and its metadata.
  4datasets:
  5- name: description
  6  dtype: text
  7  doc: Description of the imaging plane.
  8  quantity: '?'
  9- name: excitation_lambda
 10  dtype: float32
 11  doc: Excitation wavelength, in nm.
 12- name: imaging_rate
 13  dtype: float32
 14  doc: Rate that images are acquired, in Hz. If the corresponding TimeSeries is
 15    present, the rate should be stored there instead.
 16  quantity: '?'
 17- name: indicator
 18  dtype: text
 19  doc: Calcium indicator.
 20- name: location
 21  dtype: text
 22  doc: Location of the imaging plane. Specify the area, layer, comments on
 23    estimation of area/layer, stereotaxic coordinates if in vivo, etc. Use
 24    standard atlas names for anatomical regions when possible.
 25- name: manifold
 26  dtype: float32
 27  dims:
 28  - - height
 29    - width
 30    - x, y, z
 31  - - height
 32    - width
 33    - depth
 34    - x, y, z
 35  shape:
 36  - - null
 37    - null
 38    - 3
 39  - - null
 40    - null
 41    - null
 42    - 3
 43  doc: DEPRECATED Physical position of each pixel. 'xyz' represents the position
 44    of the pixel relative to the defined coordinate space. Deprecated in favor
 45    of origin_coords and grid_spacing.
 46  quantity: '?'
 47  attributes:
 48  - name: conversion
 49    dtype: float32
 50    default_value: 1.0
 51    doc: Scalar to multiply each element in data to convert it to the specified
 52      'unit'. If the data are stored in acquisition system units or other units
 53      that require a conversion to be interpretable, multiply the data by
 54      'conversion' to convert the data to the specified 'unit'. e.g. if the data
 55      acquisition system stores values in this object as pixels from x = -500 to
 56      499, y = -500 to 499 that correspond to a 2 m x 2 m range, then the
 57      'conversion' multiplier to get from raw data acquisition pixel units to
 58      meters is 2/1000.
 59    required: false
 60  - name: unit
 61    dtype: text
 62    default_value: meters
 63    doc: Base unit of measurement for working with the data. The default value
 64      is 'meters'.
 65    required: false
 66- name: origin_coords
 67  dtype: float32
 68  dims:
 69  - - x, y
 70  - - x, y, z
 71  shape:
 72  - - 2
 73  - - 3
 74  doc: Physical location of the first element of the imaging plane (0, 0) for
 75    2-D data or (0, 0, 0) for 3-D data. See also reference_frame for what the
 76    physical location is relative to (e.g., bregma).
 77  quantity: '?'
 78  attributes:
 79  - name: unit
 80    dtype: text
 81    default_value: meters
 82    doc: Measurement units for origin_coords. The default value is 'meters'.
 83    required: false
 84- name: grid_spacing
 85  dtype: float32
 86  dims:
 87  - - x, y
 88  - - x, y, z
 89  shape:
 90  - - 2
 91  - - 3
 92  doc: Space between pixels in (x, y) or voxels in (x, y, z) directions, in the
 93    specified unit. Assumes imaging plane is a regular grid. See also
 94    reference_frame to interpret the grid.
 95  quantity: '?'
 96  attributes:
 97  - name: unit
 98    dtype: text
 99    default_value: meters
100    doc: Measurement units for grid_spacing. The default value is 'meters'.
101    required: false
102- name: reference_frame
103  dtype: text
104  doc: Describes reference frame of origin_coords and grid_spacing. For example,
105    this can be a text description of the anatomical location and orientation of
106    the grid defined by origin_coords and grid_spacing or the vectors needed to
107    transform or rotate the grid to a common anatomical axis (e.g., AP/DV/ML).
108    This field is necessary to interpret origin_coords and grid_spacing. If
109    origin_coords and grid_spacing are not present, then this field is not
110    required. For example, if the microscope takes 10 x 10 x 2 images, where the
111    first value of the data matrix (index (0, 0, 0)) corresponds to (-1.2, -0.6,
112    -2) mm relative to bregma, the spacing between pixels is 0.2 mm in x, 0.2 mm
113    in y and 0.5 mm in z, and larger numbers in x means more anterior, larger
114    numbers in y means more rightward, and larger numbers in z means more
115    ventral, then enter the following -- origin_coords = (-1.2, -0.6, -2)
116    grid_spacing = (0.2, 0.2, 0.5) reference_frame = "Origin coordinates are
117    relative to bregma. First dimension corresponds to anterior-posterior axis
118    (larger index = more anterior). Second dimension corresponds to
119    medial-lateral axis (larger index = more rightward). Third dimension
120    corresponds to dorsal-ventral axis (larger index = more ventral)."
121  quantity: '?'
122groups:
123- neurodata_type_inc: OpticalChannel
124  doc: An optical channel used to record from an imaging plane.
125  quantity: +
126links:
127- name: device
128  target_type: Device
129  doc: Link to the Device object that was used to record from this electrode.

3.12.9. OpticalChannel

Extends: NWBContainer

Description: see Section 2.11.9

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: OpticalChannel
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBContainer
 3doc: An optical channel used to record from an imaging plane.
 4datasets:
 5- name: description
 6  dtype: text
 7  doc: Description or other notes about the channel.
 8- name: emission_lambda
 9  dtype: float32
10  doc: Emission wavelength for channel, in nm.

3.12.10. MotionCorrection

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.11.10

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: MotionCorrection
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3default_name: MotionCorrection
 4doc: 'An image stack where all frames are shifted (registered) to a common coordinate
 5  system, to account for movement and drift between frames. Note: each frame at each
 6  point in time is assumed to be 2-D (has only x & y dimensions).'
 7groups:
 8- neurodata_type_inc: CorrectedImageStack
 9  doc: Results from motion correction of an image stack.
10  quantity: +

3.12.11. CorrectedImageStack

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.11.11

YAML Specification:

 1neurodata_type_def: CorrectedImageStack
 2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
 3doc: Results from motion correction of an image stack.
 4groups:
 5- name: corrected
 6  neurodata_type_inc: ImageSeries
 7  doc: Image stack with frames shifted to the common coordinates.
 8- name: xy_translation
 9  neurodata_type_inc: TimeSeries
10  doc: Stores the x,y delta necessary to align each frame to the common
11    coordinates, for example, to align each frame to a reference image.
12links:
13- name: original
14  target_type: ImageSeries
15  doc: Link to ImageSeries object that is being registered.

3.13. Retinotopy

This source module contains neurodata_type for retinotopy data.

3.13.1. ImagingRetinotopy

Extends: NWBDataInterface

Description: see Section 2.12.1

YAML Specification:

  1neurodata_type_def: ImagingRetinotopy
  2neurodata_type_inc: NWBDataInterface
  3default_name: ImagingRetinotopy
  4doc: 'DEPRECATED. Intrinsic signal optical imaging or widefield imaging for measuring
  5  retinotopy. Stores orthogonal maps (e.g., altitude/azimuth; radius/theta) of responses
  6  to specific stimuli and a combined polarity map from which to identify visual areas.
  7  This group does not store the raw responses imaged during retinotopic mapping or
  8  the stimuli presented, but rather the resulting phase and power maps after applying
  9  a Fourier transform on the averaged responses. Note: for data consistency, all images
 10  and arrays are stored in the format [row][column] and [row, col], which equates
 11  to [y][x]. Field of view and dimension arrays may appear backward (i.e., y before
 12  x).'
 13datasets:
 14- name: axis_1_phase_map
 15  dtype: float32
 16  dims:
 17  - num_rows
 18  - num_cols
 19  shape:
 20  - null
 21  - null
 22  doc: Phase response to stimulus on the first measured axis.
 23  attributes:
 24  - name: dimension
 25    dtype: int32
 26    dims:
 27    - num_rows, num_cols
 28    shape:
 29    - 2
 30    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
 31      is equivalent to height, width.'
 32  - name: field_of_view
 33    dtype: float32
 34    dims:
 35    - height, width
 36    shape:
 37    - 2
 38    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
 39  - name: unit
 40    dtype: text
 41    doc: Unit that axis data is stored in (e.g., degrees).
 42- name: axis_1_power_map
 43  dtype: float32
 44  dims:
 45  - num_rows
 46  - num_cols
 47  shape:
 48  - null
 49  - null
 50  doc: Power response on the first measured axis. Response is scaled so 0.0 is
 51    no power in the response and 1.0 is maximum relative power.
 52  quantity: '?'
 53  attributes:
 54  - name: dimension
 55    dtype: int32
 56    dims:
 57    - num_rows, num_cols
 58    shape:
 59    - 2
 60    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
 61      is equivalent to height, width.'
 62  - name: field_of_view
 63    dtype: float32
 64    dims:
 65    - height, width
 66    shape:
 67    - 2
 68    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
 69  - name: unit
 70    dtype: text
 71    doc: Unit that axis data is stored in (e.g., degrees).
 72- name: axis_2_phase_map
 73  dtype: float32
 74  dims:
 75  - num_rows
 76  - num_cols
 77  shape:
 78  - null
 79  - null
 80  doc: Phase response to stimulus on the second measured axis.
 81  attributes:
 82  - name: dimension
 83    dtype: int32
 84    dims:
 85    - num_rows, num_cols
 86    shape:
 87    - 2
 88    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
 89      is equivalent to height, width.'
 90  - name: field_of_view
 91    dtype: float32
 92    dims:
 93    - height, width
 94    shape:
 95    - 2
 96    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
 97  - name: unit
 98    dtype: text
 99    doc: Unit that axis data is stored in (e.g., degrees).
100- name: axis_2_power_map
101  dtype: float32
102  dims:
103  - num_rows
104  - num_cols
105  shape:
106  - null
107  - null
108  doc: Power response on the second measured axis. Response is scaled so 0.0 is
109    no power in the response and 1.0 is maximum relative power.
110  quantity: '?'
111  attributes:
112  - name: dimension
113    dtype: int32
114    dims:
115    - num_rows, num_cols
116    shape:
117    - 2
118    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
119      is equivalent to height, width.'
120  - name: field_of_view
121    dtype: float32
122    dims:
123    - height, width
124    shape:
125    - 2
126    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
127  - name: unit
128    dtype: text
129    doc: Unit that axis data is stored in (e.g., degrees).
130- name: axis_descriptions
131  dtype: text
132  dims:
133  - axis_1, axis_2
134  shape:
135  - 2
136  doc: Two-element array describing the contents of the two response axis
137    fields. Description should be something like ['altitude', 'azimuth'] or
138    '['radius', 'theta'].
139- name: focal_depth_image
140  dtype: uint16
141  dims:
142  - num_rows
143  - num_cols
144  shape:
145  - null
146  - null
147  doc: 'Gray-scale image taken with same settings/parameters (e.g., focal depth, wavelength)
148    as data collection. Array format: [rows][columns].'
149  quantity: '?'
150  attributes:
151  - name: bits_per_pixel
152    dtype: int32
153    doc: Number of bits used to represent each value. This is necessary to
154      determine maximum (white) pixel value.
155  - name: dimension
156    dtype: int32
157    dims:
158    - num_rows, num_cols
159    shape:
160    - 2
161    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
162      is equivalent to height, width.'
163  - name: field_of_view
164    dtype: float32
165    dims:
166    - height, width
167    shape:
168    - 2
169    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
170  - name: focal_depth
171    dtype: float32
172    doc: Focal depth offset, in meters.
173  - name: format
174    dtype: text
175    doc: Format of image. Right now only 'raw' is supported.
176- name: sign_map
177  dtype: float32
178  dims:
179  - num_rows
180  - num_cols
181  shape:
182  - null
183  - null
184  doc: Sine of the angle between the direction of the gradient in axis_1 and
185    axis_2.
186  quantity: '?'
187  attributes:
188  - name: dimension
189    dtype: int32
190    dims:
191    - num_rows, num_cols
192    shape:
193    - 2
194    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
195      is equivalent to height, width.'
196  - name: field_of_view
197    dtype: float32
198    dims:
199    - height, width
200    shape:
201    - 2
202    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
203- name: vasculature_image
204  dtype: uint16
205  dims:
206  - num_rows
207  - num_cols
208  shape:
209  - null
210  - null
211  doc: 'Gray-scale anatomical image of cortical surface. Array structure: [rows][columns]'
212  attributes:
213  - name: bits_per_pixel
214    dtype: int32
215    doc: Number of bits used to represent each value. This is necessary to
216      determine maximum (white) pixel value
217  - name: dimension
218    dtype: int32
219    dims:
220    - num_rows, num_cols
221    shape:
222    - 2
223    doc: 'Number of rows and columns in the image. NOTE: row, column representation
224      is equivalent to height, width.'
225  - name: field_of_view
226    dtype: float32
227    dims:
228    - height, width
229    shape:
230    - 2
231    doc: Size of viewing area, in meters.
232  - name: format
233    dtype: text
234    doc: Format of image. Right now only 'raw' is supported.
